job_title: Anonymous Employee in Marco Island, FL
pros:
Hilton Worldwide provides great benefits and rewards to employees, even employees that are employed by franchised Hilton Properties. 

At the Marco Island location itself, some of the managers are quite competent, truly want you to succeed and are quite kind. 

The pay scale for entry level is not excellent, but higher than the average.
cons:
Management are easily threatened by individuals who inevitably express work ethic, performance and desire to succeed at their level. If you demonstrate these types of characteristics, this place is not for you. 

The management is rather incompetent. I witnessed a multi-departmental management flux in a matter of 2 weeks. 5 departments, 5 different managers (all in the "click" of upper management) and majority of the individuals confessed they were not previously experienced within the departments they are relocating too. 

They praise individuals who are rude and incompetent to make them desire remaining beneath them, rather than relocating to a different department or possibly replacing the management in position itself. 

They will make multiple accusations daily, suggesting you made the worst mistake that could possibly be done, then when they pull up the records to verify, it actually verifies the opposite of what they were accusing. 

If you get an apology for it - wow! They must be feeling sick that day. 

If you are a great employee, who strives to work in a team environment with a positive work ethic, then this is not the company for you. 

This company is extremely unethical and does not value employees beyond what Hilton Worldwide wants to be provided to all Hilton Employees.

job_title: Reservations and Customer Care in Dallas, TX
pros: Share some of the best reasons to work for Hilton?  Sorry.  Can't think of any.
cons:
This is my second time around at Hilton, and why I ever thought that a leopard would change it's spots is beyond me!  They will lie to you, worse than a used car salesman.  And once you've onboarded, all of a sudden, they change the story.  They lie about schedules, they lie about time off, they lie about wages, and worst of all, they lie about job duties.  They tell you it's customer service, which is about the furthest thing from the truth.  It's sales.  Commissioned sales.  And if you don't reach their sales goals, they take away your preferred schedule.  Which means, if you have children or other responsibilities, they will come in second.  They also ask you to not tell the guests calling to make a reservation that you are not on property.  Another lie, albeit of omission.  They don't want folks to know that every call is counted in your metrics.  If you don't book a room on that call, your metrics start to fall.  So that person who just wants a little information dings your numbers, and can be treated with less care than someone who wants to book even just one room.  
***Note***  The location below is incorrect.  Hilton now has many agents, like myself, who work at home.  But glassdoor's system insists on a location so I used Dallas, as that is where there headquarters are.

review_title: Great place to work with many opportunities
pros:
I am a new hire at Hilton and have experienced nothing but great things so far. My team was welcoming from the get-go and communication with upper management has been steady (something I find imperative for success in the workplace). One of my favorite things about working for Hilton is our travel stay benefits/discounts. I have been able to travel to places like Mexico and Austin Texas, staying in hotels for unbelievably cheap prices. Even more cool is that similar  benefits can be shared with your friends/family. 
Another aspect of working for Hilton is that after 6 months, employees have an optional "work from home" day. You are also granted 20 paid time off days your first year, and 25 PTO thereon (not including holidays). It is understood at Hilton that life is not all about work - it is also about having fun and enjoying life.
I could go on and on about all the great things about working for Hilton. But I would rather you discover for yourself. If you have the opportunity to apply here, by all means, do it! You have nothing to lose and everything to gain.
cons: Some days are long and tasks can be repetitive. But good days easily outnumber the more difficult days.

job_title: Programmer Analyst Lead in Memphis, TN
pros:
Hilton has a team member travel program that allows employees to stay at Hilton properties at discounted rates.  Although I have never once been able to get an "Employee" room at any hotel without personally calling the hotels general manager, it is possible to get "Family" rates which, although they are not free, are discounted from the properties normal nightly rate.

Depending on what projects in IT you work in, there is some opportunity to work with some of the latest Microsoft technology.  If you happen to work of one of these groups there are some really great toys to play with.
cons:
Hilton's corporate offices are very bloated with middle management.  Layer after layer of bureaucracy that impedes the company from making any real progress.  The Blackstone Group, who now owns Hilton is about to make a massive round of cuts and in the near future this may no longer be the case.  Only time will tell.

Corporate as a whole, has little or no project management processes in place to allow projects to be managed effectively.  In most instances projects are successful in spite of themselves.  If you can stand the utter lack of organization and the mind numbing bureaucracy, Hilton will be a fine place for you to work.

pros:
it is a known brand

cons:

pros: I enjoy Hilton because it's a global company and there's opportunity or potential to live or work in another city, state or country. Hilton invests in their employees and encourages wellness and work-life balance.  Wages and benefits are fair and competitive with other companies.  I especially enjoy the travel perks!
cons: Systems and technology is behind the times.  How about developing mobile applications for Grand Wailea and other resorts with mobile pushes for events and happenings, partnering with Apple Pay in the outlets and retail shops, using MENUPOINT.NET or a similar wireless system for poolside food and beverage and cabana service.

pros: Once in a blue moon it is possible to get employee hotel rates. It might require a miracle from a divine being though in order to be possible.
cons: They laid off thousands of employees with an automated email. That speaks volumes to company culture. My bosses never reached out. HR never reached out. And we were given 10 days notice, in the middle of a pandemic and the worst economy in decades. Hilton was voted #1 place to work, but that's a massive joke. All management cares about is increasing profits so they can have bigger bonuses.  This is why the hotel employees make so little yet the prices of the hotels are out of control. Management is so out of touch with the reality that people faced when they were furloughed. Their resource site for furloughed employees was full of wellness tips and how to relax, do yoga, etc. I don't know about everyone else but the last thing a real human being like me wants to hear from their company when they've lost their income is how to take deep calming breaths. This Company is a joke. Just apply to Marriott instead. They at least treat their employees with a basic level of human decency.

review_title: Save Yourself Some Time and Look & Work Elsewhere
pros: The only PRO for the many years I worked there is the ability to work from home. I am not just a disgruntled employee. Items were promised during hiring that never transpired.
cons:
The advancements within the virtual call center are a joke.  Most of the opportunities are TDP (meaning Temporary Development Pool). These advancements are not permanent, nor is any bump in hourly pay. 

Office politics is a thing, even when you work from home.

Virtual call center senior management was recently changed in the last year or so and a lot of the items "she" implemented had a negative effect on the employees on the front lines.

I worked there for many years and felt very UNappreciated. Annual raises even for a great employee with great stats is less than 50 cents.

Flexibility in schedules is not really flexible if you are required to work based on "business needs".  "You are free to pick the hours you want to work based on the hours we have available is not really flexible." That does not allow the employee the flexibility you are telling them is available.

I am a thoroughly qualified employee that was reliable, flexible, worked hard, went above and beyond what was asked or expected...

review_title: Used to be a great company but awful now.
pros: IT at the operations center in Memphis used to be at the good end of a firehose of money, but the good old days are clearly over.  Now the best thing about the place is free coffee.  But they've stopped giving away cups.
cons: With (I think) a few groups that are notable exceptions, IT management is frustratingly inept.  They will be very nice to you and give you lots of money (well, they would until about 6 months ago) but they are incapable of differentiating between good work and gross incompetence. People are being laid off rapidly; sadly your chances of going away don't seem at all related to your usefulness to the company.

review_title: Fast Growing Company with a Global Reputation
pros: Fast growing company with a bright future, leader in the hospitality business with a global reputation, well-intentioned culture and values, senior management makes a genuine effort to do the right thing when it comes to employees and for the most part encourage and support career growth and upward movement within departments. great discounts and employee rates on hotels and resorts around the country
cons: Poor compensation for operations-level positions, changes in company programs and policies are not always implemented seamlessly due to disconnect between corporate level and individual hotel properties, hotel properties that are too large tend to foster a culture of politics and bureaucracy that does not always align with the company's values, there are many internal opportunities but open positions tend to be filled by local candidates only and out of state candidates are not always seriously considered which can be frustrating when one has a desire to relocate

review_title: Great Hospitality Company, Some Execs Could Use Work
pros: Good benefits, the Team Member Travel program is alright when you can get it to work. It's fun to work for the number one hotel company in the world- nice to feel like you're a part of something bigger that keeps growing every day.
cons: Team Member Travel Program needs some serious work, like I said, it's nice when you can get it to work for you, but most of the time nothing you want is available. Your hotel's EC could be full of some people who don't care about their teams (like mine) yet corporate thinks they're gold. Also there's no such thing as work/life balance here, but such is the industry.

review_title: Good place to work, challenging, fast-paced and global
pros: Realize that my perspective is that of a Senior Director level position with HWW corporate- I imagine the reviews will vary according to role, location, etc.  The corporate leadership for Hilton is, for the most part, outstanding.  Those in C-level positions are smart, approachable and respectful- particularly in brand leadership and marketing.  The perks are good, particularly if you like to travel, and the people around the world are fun to work with.  There are some that are difficult, mostly legacy types, but not any more than anywhere else.
cons: It's a big company, so decisions can linger. There is quite a bit of arrogance with the Americas Sales operation- they think they're the elite of the company- and sometimes treat others that way- but that should be improving, as there's been a reorganization there.  The team member travel discount program is pretty bad- there's a lot of talk to improve it.    Compensation isn't especially high on average.

review_title: It’s like high school all over again

You would have to get there early just so you had time to go on a scavenger hunt to locate what you need. They also never seemed to have enough staff so if you know how to do multiple positions more than likely they will just put you  wherever they see fit without any kind of heads up (could even be a different department). They never  follow through when you bring a concern to their attention, they also like to have “team meetings” which are more like lashings. They would basically tell you everything you are doing wrong and they liked to  belittle  their employees.  There was often issues with scheduling, they say they are flexible and will work with your schedule but often wasn’t the case.

cons: Forced PTO. When I came on board the Sales Office was closed 3x in the next 3 months. I had no time off so I didn't get paid for those vacation times. I hear a lot of "when I was at my old property".. well you're no longer there so shut up about it. Making staff changes and not explaining how it's benefiting the property.

pros: Hilton Worldwide is the most amazing company to work for.  The footprint they represent in the hospitality industry is an amazing culture.  The culture is exactly where I want to be in my career.  I have also made the most money I ever have by exceeding my bonus structure.  The benefits (hospitalization, etc.) are better than what I could imagine.    There is unlimited potential for growth into higher positions, and the hiring process is long but worth the wait.  They only want the best.
cons: On property level our executive committee could display more leadership vs. politics.  They need to present themselves a step above everyone else, instead of playing politics.   We are the number 2 place to work in the world, and sometimes my team and I don't feel like it is the number 2 place to work.   The Pro's outweigh the con's however wish our EC team would conduct themselves just as such, an executive committee.

pros: Hilton Corporation is a Great Company to work for because of their Benefits Package.  Great Options for Health Insurance, 401K Matches up to 7% and you are Fully Vest, PTO time is accumulated from Day One and accumulation of PTO is based on the Hours worked and last the Team Member Travel Benefits.
cons: The Hilton Anatole has 1,606 Hotel Rooms one of the largest hotels in the Dallas Market Center with the lowest pay scale. The Low Pay Scale effects every Entry Level Position as well as Management Position.  The Hilton Anatole has declined drastically from what its Well Known Notoriety. I believe the Hilton Anatole is "On Fumes" and so is the Hospitality, Service and Morale.

pros: well done good peps great service luxuries
cons: no cons are given all good can work all day

review_title: They Demand Your Soul with Little in Return
pros: The prestige of working for a top name can't be beat, as long as that is enough for you. For employees entering into the company, stick with a franchised hotel. They are usually run a lot more realistically than a property run by the corporation.
cons: As most companies today, they only look at the bottom line. They forget about everything above that line that  produces it...the people. Conrad Hilton put people first, thus creating the greatest hotel company in the world. Sorry to say he'd be embarrassed to see his company today. In a hotel owned or managed by the corporation, more and more is demanded from less and less staff. Salaries in a corporate run hotel are far less than their franchised competitors. Employees on every level feel the burden of smaller staffs and increased occupancies, thus creating truly unrealistic workloads. They contribute to the 70% industry-wide turnover rate.

review_title: Decent company; not much room for growth without a degree
pros: I'll preface by saying, I personally love working for Hilton. They have great benefits and perks, kind management, and invest the money necessary to make their employees jobs safe to perform, and do so efficiently.
cons: They make it very difficult to move into a supervisory or managerial position without having a degree. Or, more accurately, you simply get overlooked if you dont have a degree. They also tend to hire from outside the company instead of promoting from within, which makes it hard to advance once you're locked into a position.

review_title: Lots of customer service for little pay
pros:
AMAZING benefits- health insurance, pto/vacation, school reimbursement, deep discount on hotel rooms

Majority of coworkers and employees are extremely nice and willing to help, except for the occasional few here and there

Very nice hotel and place to work. Also offers free meals during your breaks. Makes sure you do not work more than 6 hours without a break.

When it's slow there's lots of downtime to chat with your coworkers and the guests.
cons:
The pay is very low for the amount of customer issues and service you have to deal with on a regular basis. Half of the guests are friendly and thankful, the others will treat you like their servants and think they are so much better than you. 

There is also a LOT to learn on the computer - it's not an easy system to learn and it's very easy to make a glitch that will bite you in the behind later - and someone will come find you to complain about it later.

job_title: Guest Service/MOD/Night Audit in Denver, CO
pros: Competitive pay, excellent working conditions,friendly and knowledgeable GM and AGM's.  All upper management and human resources are very friendly, communicative, and eager to assist in employee and guest concerns. The upper management team really stand brindle the Hilton Promis, and their employees 110% of the time.
cons:
There are no benefits for general employees.  The company does advertise as offering benefits to future prospect to lure them into applying.  No PTO, no medical/dental, no 401k... A company as large as Hilton should offer benefits, medical at the very least.  
The only other concern is the work loadcab be exhausting at times.  As a HGI, Hampton, and Embassy Suit firmer employee Ive experienced it first hand.  Your expected to work whenever and wherever THEY needyou, even if it's not YOUR jobs duties.

job_title: Sales Director in Austin Gardens Colonia, TX
pros: Corporate discounts, health insurance, etc
cons: Long hours, long hours, long hours

pros: Good reputation. Hilton continues to hold a lot of weight in the hotel industry careerwise for your resume.
cons: Corporate Hotels (owned and/or managed by Hilton Corporation as opposed to a franchised property) --- continually short staffed due to continually decreasing budgets. Management is asked each year to do more on less and for less. Employees at the entry level feel it also as they too have to do more and more for less and less. Hilton has changed...was once the leader in the Hospitality Industry...is now the Hospitality BUSINESS. The corporation only cares about one thing...the bottom line, with absolutely no regard for the employees that make that goal. Check into a corporate hotel sometime and a franchised hotel...notice the difference in the employees. In a corporate hotel, most employees are overworked and it shows in their attitude.

pros: Hilton was family.  The benefits were amazing and the people were even more amazing-er!!  The learning and advancement  opportunities were plentiful!!  As a manager, it was required to have so many hours of classes per year and the class calendar was always posted at the beginning of every year!!  They were extremely useful for and work and personal.  Hilton is where I had gained most of my business knowledge.  I had met life long friends from around the world.  But sadly, it was time to move on to new adventures!!
cons: It was a 24/7 operation and the holidays were long, but wasn't that bad because the people made it fun!

review_title: No work/life balance for very meager compensation
job_title: Assistant Restaurant Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Worked with some nice people, Hilton employee perks (that would have been great if you ever actually were allowed to take time off), great 401k package and full benefits.
cons: terrible hours, compensation, time-off policies, having less respect and benefits than the employees you are managing (unionized), lack of control, lack of opportunities to move up. The hours (between 10-12 a day, and 5-6 days a week) sometimes ran into each other, where you would be working 3pm–2am, take a nap at the hotel, then open the restaurants at 6am and work until 3pm again. No consideration given in either compensation or future requests for time off.

pros: great company with great reputation, ability to move around if you want
cons:
the home training is ridiculous!!! the modules are WAY to o many too much information stuffing makes it hard for the agent to maintain what is important!! The PAY SUCKS!!! 9.00 an hour with the POSSIBILITY of incentives is not enough for all you have to remember whether it is work from home or not. 
When during the interview it should be emphasized the extra monies that could be made per reservation is based solely on "metrics" and  it is NOT a definite 1.00 or more!
Pay like that from such a well-known company is actually a little pitiful

pros: You get a lot of PTO
cons: Can we say BULLY Tactics.   Lets start with Director and VP level leadership.  The director and VP level management is immature and unprofessional. Working for Hilton I felt like I was in high school again. If you are not apart of the clique you are out.  The leadership provides little vision and no support.  They create a culture of discord and disrespect. I have never seen a group like this. Everyone there treated me like crap and I never truly got an opportunity to thrive. Also, they work in silos and never come together as a team.  There is a lot of finger pointing and throwing each other under the bus.  Now the work, I have not seen a single project go out effectively, this is due to not working together.  I forgot to mention they lead by fear and not respect.. It was a Nightmare.  I will never work for Hilton again.. Also not open to new people coming in.. If you have not been with the group for 10 to 15 years, start kissing up.. only way to survive

pros: Hilton is an amazing place to work for.  The company commits to building an incredible brand of hotels, commits to ensuring the best guest experience, commits to supporting the various communities and projects, and commits to their employees.  There have been many changes and improvements over the last five years.  To be honest, it's too much to list.  This company is fun.  This company focuses on their people.  There are changes with any company striving to be better and you go through some growing pains but overall, it's a commitment to be better.  There is a lot of focus on work/life balance and understand that everyone has their own personal things to deal with.  As long as you do your work, doing something simple as going to the doctor or picking up kids isn't something we worry about here.  There is flexibility in working from home as well.  Great place!
cons: Organizational structure changes can slow things down a bit but it's working to improve how we also produce from the business perspective as well.  Not a bad thing.

pros: It's a family of incredibly talented professionals that enjoy and respect each other and their ideas. The collaborative spirit is a joy to experience daily and provides a learning and sharing environment. With everybody's primary focus being to provide every guest/customer (inside and out) an excellent user and guest experience, while ensuring each individual is able to constantly develop in their area of expertise by growing their scope of knowledge and adding specialties while being the leader in the industry.
cons: Sometimes it takes longer to projects completed and implemented due to the size of the organization. However, this is always a focus and improving consistently.

pros: Hilton cares. I know that's hard to believe with almost 4,000 hotels, each with hundreds of employees working to keep it running, but Hilton really does care. And the benefits are awesome! It doesn't matter if you are a part-time dishwasher or the Hotel Manager, you get benefits: corporate discounts, better room rates, $ towards your 401k, paid time off, etc etc etc. The people that work at Hilton, for the most part, are amazing and want to see a smile on your face! I am just a hostess at the restaurant inside the hotel, but I feel comfortable hanging out with the housekeepers as well as the Department heads-- everyone gets along because everyone has the same mission: keep the guests happy. Hilton is actually my 2nd job, but I never feel anything but excited when I go to work
cons: It is a big corporation, so, as much as everyone gets along, their main focus is the department they work in.

review_title: Pleasant and positive place to work most of the time.
pros: The benefits walking in are pretty good considering that I'm only On-Call/Banquet-Server. Team members are really cool to work with most of the time, and its usually all smiles all day. Easy work environment and down to earth boss's.
cons: Favoritism gets completely out of control most of the time. No one's generally held accountable for their actions. We have high levels of immaturity that can cause unnecessary work difficulty. Lack of consistent hours and last second cancellation's. Mangers are mostly on point but tend to be easily detracted and lose focus of job responsibilities. Full-time employees complain alot about Part-Time employees getting as many hours as them; but generally themselves don't follow the standard that they've complained about. Since we're union they make multiple excuses and complain about everything almost all the time.

pros: Maybe the free food. Otherwise, nothing.
cons: Went for a Marketing Coordinator position interview. The information online said it was for a salary position. When I got to the interview, I was told that the pay was $9 (minimum wage) and I would be working at the Concierge desk selling Timeshare. I took the job because I was desperate for a second job. They wanted us to talk to every guest coming up to us about Timeshare...Also, the manager only showed up to our hotel maybe once or twice a month. She lied in the interview saying they sold about 1-3 timeshare packages a day and I found out from the other coworkers that it was about 3 packages in 6 months! She tried to make us sign a piece of paper stating that we would get fired if we didn't sell 15 packages a month. The hotel would take our commissions we get from rental car companies, tours, reservations, etc and tell us we would get fired if they caught us taking them. Most other staff in the hotel are rude and unprofessional.

pros: small but great and efficient banqueting team. A few good benefits
cons: low salary considering the long shifts and no overtime paid.  It's all very smoking mirrors. Managers pretend to be nice, however, not very open to listening to feedback or discuss any issues. It's a "like it or leave it" culture. Low moral due to extensive work hours without any sort of compensation or appreciation

review_title: Great Job to Build a Career
pros:
You can move around with Hilton and work from home. I am building a house, and will be able to take my job with me when I love. The training environment was fantastic and really simulated the calls we would take. I felt as prepared as I could be to take calls on day one. The benefits are fantastic with a wide range of health options to choose from. There is also dental, a 401k with company match, paid holidays, paid time off, sick time, time off after having a child for mothers and fathers, disability benefits, company paid life insurance, travel benefits, and a team member assistance program for life issues.

You are provided most of the equipment you will need, and there is room for growth while still staying at home.
cons: My particular trainer did a great job, but was relatively new to the company and got a couple points incorrect. There are a few items the team member will need to supply to work from home.

pros: Great benefits and employee perks.  Some friendly people.  You can build your own schedule.
cons:
They are transitioning to a new system so the new hires are learning that.  The existing employees are on the old system, so that's created some discourse and limits who the new employees can go to for help.  Additionally, the system was rolled out before it was fully functional, so the newbs have to transfer alot of guests to the users of the old system -- greatly affects conversion rates, which is how you make your money in this department.

Additionally, you can't move from FT to PT or the reverse.  They will tell you  that you can, but it rarely happens, Even if they are currently hiring for the time you want to move to.  I would think they'd give current employees an opportunity to move into those time slots before before hiring someone new.  There are alot of disgruntled employees because of this.  The perks are nice, but they will only make an employee stay so long.

pros: Great benefits and employee perks.  Some friendly people.  You can build your own schedule.
cons:
They are transitioning to a new system so the new hires are learning that.  The existing employees are on the old system, so that's created some discourse and limits who the new employees can go to for help.  Additionally, the system was rolled out before it was fully functional, so the newbs have to transfer alot of guests to the users of the old system -- greatly affects conversion rates, which is how you make your money in this department.

Additionally, you can't move from FT to PT or the reverse.  They will tell you  that you can, but it rarely happens, Even if they are currently hiring for the time you want to move to.  I would think they'd give current employees an opportunity to move into those time slots before before hiring someone new.  There are alot of disgruntled employees because of this.  The perks are nice, but they will only make an employee stay so long.

pros: Hilton provides excellent opportunities for individuals who are willing to take up a challenge. Over the past years being employed by Hilton, every challenge has been awarded with an opportunity to grow. You feel like you are one big family here with great leaders & mentors! there is always an inspiring story to tell. You always have that feeling that you are part of something great. I look forward to waking up each morning and going to work. Career opportunities are endless, we are rich in culture with strong values, recognition is mind blowing & our working environment here makes you feel like a guest! We have an online university with thousands of free courses to choose from. There are study bursaries available, Excellent leadership programmes, Friends & Family get discounted rates, employees get free accommodation, discounted food & beverage & meals are provided on duty. Lots of travel opportunities. Hilton is just a great place to work!
cons: We have so many hotels that its impossible to visit all in one lifetime working at Hilton...

review_title: Love this company and my Job. It is a company where you can learn and grow at a fast pace.
pros: Travel benefits and educational benefits are amazing. There is no limit to education with Hilton University. You can learn ahead for hat position or advancement you want.
cons:
Management forgets you exist when you work the graveyard shift. There is no recognition or recommendations for the Graveyard shift where I currently work for. 

I mean it literally. We get reviewed quarterly I personally have great reviews from guests that stay with us and those who are or were just visiting the property. And my colleagues also do there maximum best. But when it comes to the recognition we are forgotten. Most of my colleagues already are demotivated. We love the guest some are now like Family. And they are why we come to work with a smile still.

pros:
Great Team Member Travel Program and F&F perks 
Great internal communication with the Hilton Lobby and weekly required brand newsletters 
Cool initiatives that employees can get into like Hilton Careers, Hilton Careers on Snapchat and Hilton Suggests (travel blog)
cons:
Marketing Manager job descriptions vary from hotel to hotel 
Most Marketing Managers seem to come from other industries than hotels where (depending on your hotel) most of the Operations people and sales people are straight hotel people - it can be difficult advocating for certain things you want when others don't have agency or non-hotel experience  
Little money at the hotel level for content (photos, stock photos, photography, etc)

review_title: Decent perks, but very inflexible job.
pros: Great perks like free and discounted hotel rooms, on site gourmet coffee. Hotels from around the country would set up tables and hand out freebies.
cons: Nearly impossible to change your shift. I was hired for the 10-6 shift, which was all that was available at the time. I put in a request to change to the morning shift, for when it became available. They refused unless I gave them a letter from a university or another employer showing my current shift conflicted with school or another job - -that is the only reason they will accept for a shift change. They won't let you change due to family obligations, or any other reason! The next day they advertised jobs for the shift I requested, and hired a bunch of new employees giving them the hours that I requested. Some promotions are based solely on seniority. Low pay.

pros: Great leadership, great benefits, forward thinking, empowerment of employees, upper management actually cares about employees. Worked in several departments of my hotel, and loved the 5 years I spent there.
cons: Not as much cohesion between hotel departments as I'd like to see

review_title: Heard good things about other Hilton properties, this one is just not great to work at.
pros: Hotel discounts. Fifty percent off food.
cons: Almost impossible to get a raise. You either get around 20 hours when you tell them that you can work any shifts they have and are always on call ready to help, or you'll work 60 hours a week (which you'll get yelled at for) because they decide to fire the only two other workers leaving you and one other worker to work every shift, every single day. No breaks. No days off. Until they hire a couple of people which take about a month because of how long they take to get the drug and background tests done. You will never feel appreciated.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Watford, England
pros:
Staff discounts on all company hotels under Hilton Brand (depending on availability). Example: Curio Hilton in Ibiza is usually £500 per night you can get it done £35. 

Can be lots of job opportunities if you’re looking to climb up the ladder. Can transfer move abroad to work as it’s a multinational brand. 

Meet lots of people from different backgrounds and nationalities.  

Management will teach you things, if you ask, to help you get comfortable and make transitioning to a higher position easier. 

Staff in all departments are lovely, more like a family away from home than colleagues.
cons:
Sometimes hotel will overspend on hours meaning you’ll get less hours than you’re contracted a month. 

Apparently only allowed to have 1 weekend off a month but you’ll be lucky if you get that. 

Can work up to 8/9 days in a row without a day off (not always, usually if lots of people are on holiday) 

Unsocialable hours

(( Pros definitely outweigh the cons ))

pros: So glad I made the switch to Hilton! After 28 years at a service industry leader, I didn't think it could get better, but I'm thrilled to be at Hilton.  The global corporate culture is as genuine on the inside as what you see from the outside. Strong sense of accountability and teamwork, strong work ethic across all levels and strong advocacy for our customers. It's good to feel good about what I do every day and know I can make a difference.
cons: This is a small 'big company' so work teams are tasked with alot.  The sense of collaboration and shared goals is a huge help.  You'll never be bored and will be challenged to stretch your thinking often.  The opportunity to innovate in this space is huge, so being naturally curious and open to new ideas is a must!

pros: Work from home, some agents can build their own schedule.
cons: They have reduced our travel benefits to the point the public can find better rates than we get. We can only stay 30 nights a year. They also rip off our customers with resort fees, and increased the amount of points to make a reservations.  They have farmed out jobs to the Philipines and San Salvador and the customers expense. These agents charge the customer hundreds and thousands of dollars to purchase points instead of acting in the best interest of the customer and reserving with the customers promotional certificates or advising the customer of the cost. They are little more than talking monkeys and then we (domestic agents) have to fix the messes they create.

review_title: Good experience for those interested in the service industry.
job_title: Loss Prevention Agent in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working at a Hilton hotel gives you a first class glimpse of how the service industry is and should be run. Customer satisfaction is what you are selling and what better place to get started than a world renown, multinational hotel like the Hilton. Great place to work on your acting skills as well.
cons: The scheduling can get very backwards at times because this business is open 24/7/365. You might get stuck in swing or graveyard shift. Upper management is where you want to be.

pros: When Media at The Anatole is busy, it is really good. There is a lot of money to be made when the hotel is busy. There are also nice perks with your mobile carrier and nice room discounts.
cons: Media at The Anatole doesn't get much outside business. When the hotel is below 30% there is no money to be made at Media. Half the managers are new, and the other half have been there a few years or so. For whatever reason they hate to make cuts. There is tooooo much down time for the servers there. The majority of the servers are well over 45 so they don't trust any of the servers to big sections.

review_title: A Great Company Truly Dedicated to their Team Members
job_title: Senior Catering Sales Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Hilton is so great at valuing and recognizing their team members, through monthly Team Member of the Month and Manager of the Quarter Celebrations, to an annual trip for the top Sales People in the company. 
This company truly believes in providing us with the tools and resources needed to get our job done (company phones, laptops, etc.)
A pretty good employee Travel Plan offering highly discounted rooms (including for Friends or Family)
Major opportunities to grow and get promoted.
Hilton Employees are extremely loyal. Most colleagues have been at the same property for 12+ years.
The sales world offers extremely competitive salaries and benefits and clearly attracts the best people in the business. Many people long to get in with this company.
cons: Not many cons that I can honestly think of. As a current employee, because of the company being a public entity, there is a bit higher pressure to ensure accurate results in regard to financial performance; not really a "con" but something to consider.

review_title: Excellent Place to Work, LOVE My Job
job_title: Night Auditor in Melbourne Beach, FL
pros: Days worked are flexible, travel benefits are outstanding, managers listen and frequently ask for feedback on decisions, employees are truly empowered to make decisions for guests, team-focused, nice area to work in (clean, AC, fully stocked with supplies)
cons: Audit is limited to only 1 shift per day, where as front desk is 2, so less opportunity to pick up extra shifts. Little opportunity to take part in team decision making because of shift worked.

job_title: Director of Front Office in Dallas, TX
pros: Working for Hilton for 10 years, and what a ride. After being promoted 5 times, working at 5 different hotels, in 4 different states, I believe I can truly say Hilton is a wonderful company to work for. Compensation is fair and aggressive within the hospitality brand, benefits are industry leading and have even been highlighted in the news in 2016. Hilton is a fair employer, with a strong culture that rewards hard work and is committed to its teams. Come join us.
cons: We always wonder if the grass is greener on the other side (its normal). Every job has its ups and downs, and I believe Hilton has taken team member feedback well, and developed solutions to improve the quality of life for its team. I would like to see affordable child care assistance considered as a benefit for us, but am happy with the progress Hilton has made towards benefits so over the years. We are going in the "right" direction.

job_title: Assistant Director of Finance in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: Hilton is literally a Family and I feel it every day. It's a company that cares a lot about the opinions and growth of their employees and provide all the tools for personal development. I'm really proud to work in this company and I don't believe I will ever have a reason to leave it... I LOVE IT and I LOVE MY JOB!!
cons: In order to be promoted to certain positions (Director Level) it is sometimes required to leave the country or move from the current Hotel which shouldn't be a must if the person is talented but unfortunately it is still an assumption that is quite common in big hotel chains across the globe. Nonetheless I've seen an inversion of this trend within Hilton and hope to see it more and more in the future...

review_title: There are great learning opportunities with hard work and loyalty at Hilton.
job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: I am proud of the name and I enjoy travel opportunities.  Hilton is in the leading edge of hospitality technology.  If your primary goal of your job is to learn new technologies you would do well here.
cons: It is still a good old boy corporation with only a few (well publicized) exceptions.  Those who can spin and say yes without any resistance are recognized as successful and those who point out the risks and try to mitigate them are seen as non-team players.  Expectation management is impossible and if you want life balance, you will not find it in Hilton’s IT department.

review_title: If you are not in the Union, do not expect a pay increase.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Saratoga Springs, NY
pros: Great entry level positions, good opportunities for interns, travel benefits and wonderful free online training tools and resources.
cons: If you work for an owned and managed hotel, do not expect a pay increase unless you are a union member.  There is a disparity among staff in that most of the administrators are hourly, all are female and none have received a pay increase of more than .50 more than once in the last three years.

pros: Hilton Worldwide has some of the best benefits around.  Five weeks paid vacation after 1 year, 10 weeks maternity leave and 2 weeks paternity leave, and $10,000 towards adoption services!  These are just a few of the reasons I love working for this company.
cons: Growth within the company is a great possibility but when you move from position to position within Hilton, there is a 10% cap on promotions.  It can be difficult knowing where you are on the pay scale compared to other team mates that joined from outside the company.

pros: While many outstanding employees "resigned" after the Blackstone acquisition, there are still quite a few terrific people here - the "old" regime brand management team that is still in place are great leaders who can take the company where it needs to go, despite the obstacles that senior management puts in the way. The company is very forward-thinking, especially in these bad economic times.
cons: Since the acquisition by Blackstone, the company has lost so many good people. And, the new senior leadership doesn't seem to care about any impact on existing employees nor do they put forth a sincere effort at making this a good place to work where people can be proud. It'll be interesting to see what happens after the probable IPO happens sometime in 2011 or 2012.

review_title: I think it was a learning experience of why it is important to go to college get a degree and a good job.
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I like the fact that we get great employee discounts. I also like the fact that we get sick pay. The best part is networking with the customers you never know who you will meet.
cons: The worst thing is sometimes management is shady and try to take advantage of all the work you are willing to do. You only get insurance if you average at least 32 hours and that is very hard in the slow season.  As with most jobs it is hard to move up when you don't know anyone and some managers show favor to friends and family.

review_title: Mixed Bag of Benefits and Problems...
pros: Busy, full of people and activity.  In the town square shopping area so there's most always something going on and that brings people into the hotel.  Very busy late night bar.
cons: Overly busy with drunks coming out of the bar and functions.  GM's policy of prohibiting the staff from throwing troublemakers out of the hotel hamstrings employees and causes affected parties to have to flee the hotel.  More than one positive experience has been ruined as in the reviews.  It's nearly impossible for trouble making employees to get counseled let alone fired which roils employees that have to work with them.  There is little if any positive communications, you more often then not only hear from management when you've done something wrong.  The back of  the hotel is usually filthy if not a mess with overflowing and smelly trash cans that apparently no one empties.  Roaches and insects have been seen in the back offices along with food and drinks left out.

review_title: Hilton Hotels - A Company in Transition
pros: I had the great pleasure of working for Hilton Hotels while it was still the preeminent hotel company in the world.  Many of the finest people I've known and worked with came through Hilton's corporate structure.  It was a very large family, where everyone had a stake in our collective success.
cons: Since the acquisition by Blackstone, the very structure of the company is changing.  While I'm confident the company will once more be a world leader, it has not yet found it's footing.  Many great people have moved on, voluntarily and otherwise, with an air of uncertainty weighing heavily upon those who remain.

job_title: Bar Porter in New Orleans, LA
pros: nobody watches over you, you get the hours you want and then some, overtime welcomed, never bored unless it's really slow, get to talk to and meet people from all over, management was easy to talk to, pay can be great but you earn every dollar
cons: when it's busy, it's hectic and sometimes unbearable when other bar porters leave you the workload just because their shift ended or whatever, no teamwork much of the time, some lazy bartenders and servers, even if it's half-busy, your workload is still heavy because of your job description, constantly moving and lifting while everyone asks you for more favors, etc...

review_title: Solid company with a couple departmental issues
pros: Hilton takes pretty good care of their people; salaries are fair, benefits are good, and PTO is more than adequate.  People seem to get from their jobs there (both in terms of promotion and retention) what they put into them, which isn't the case everywhere.  Expectations for performance have been high but not unreasonable, in my experience.  This is a good place to work.
cons: At least on the eCommerce side, getting meaningful things done can be frustrating, since you're not only having to get buy-in from 10 brands, but also dealing with a number of territorial departments that don't want to share their toys.  The department also can't seem to figure out what it wants to be or what its goals are, which can leave employees wondering if they are there to provide customer service to hotels, improve the websites, or drive revenue.  It's a fairly young department so this will mostly likely get better, but there are currently growing pains.

job_title: Guest Service Representative in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great relationship with co-management .  Vacation   is 5 days per year, insurance is reasonable, and the holiday party is very nice.
cons: The hotel is old and the hallways and rooms smell like mold.  The kitchen is always dirty, a d roaches were crawling on the steam table.  The General Manager offers no assistance, and never leaves his office.  I was promised bonuses that I never recieved. There are no supplies to work with such as silverware,glasses, and coffee cups.  The meal plan for their employees is terrible, and restaurant managers never have a chance to eat.  Restaurant Managers work 65 hours a week for less than 32,000 a year!

pros:
The most positive thing that I believe is the most important as well is the opportunities for our team members.  Our every day work is appreciated, valued and we are cared for. We have a lot of development opportunities within the company. Different  trainings, workshops and programmes allow me to develop my self as future leader. What I like the most is also the fact that each team member has empowerment . We can make decisions on our own and thus we see what is wrong and what is right. 
I also appreciate the fact the company gives us opportunities to cross and switch the departments so that we become professionals in the industry.
cons: The changes taking place in the organisation are very rapid, sometimes it is very hard to follow and understand all of them, while the knowledge of all the things are extremely important.

pros: Discounted hotel rooms at team member rates.
cons:
I’ve been with the company 5 1/2 years now. Everything is going down hill. From the systems we use that are barely even functional most of the time to the small
Window of opportunities for advancement to the lack of ability to earn the “bonus” which was promised to be a certain amount upon being hired. The job duties were recently changed without anyone’s knowledge which took away reservation agents ability to earn incentives. We used to take reservation calls ONLY now we take whatever call is being sent our way yet we are still held accountable for SALES METRICS, very very unfair. Very LOW hourly pay compared to other comparable hotels. Yearly raises are in the very low pennies. They change company policies without giving proper notices you have to find out through a co worker or in chat if you’re a work at home agent. I would not recommend this to a friend or a family member.

pros: A great company but hospitality has not changed , its usually lower pay,  and guest do not TIP the way it once was (location matters)  If money is good, there is  less a loss or turn over of staff.   However not all staff is kept with good choice.
cons: TIPs have gotten cheaper so pay should be better  and some questionable people in management . management does not get involved and allow lazy employees.   They often over look a good employee.

job_title: Senior, Catering & Conference Service Manager in Wailea, HI
pros: Hilton just keeps getting better and better in the way the think about and care for team members.  Recent enhancements to the team member experience is a better and brighter back of house,  Team Member Cafeteria improvements, and the best yet is lifetime employee or Friends and Family Rates for team members meeting requirements for years of service.
cons: I honestly cant think of any.  I have worked for 3 of the major hotel corporations and I find Hilton to be the best.  Working in hotels is not for everyone.  The hotel never closes and it is a daily responsibility to go out of your way for each and every guest.  You will find out quickly if this environment makes your thrive.

review_title: Good place to work if you can stand the lack of organization
job_title: Lead Programmer Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: #1 for me is people.  I really like working with my immediate and extended team.  We have a broad set of backgrounds, experience, and skill sets.  While we are generally quite busy (or overloaded) with projects, we're always given the latitude to attack problems with our own perspective (assuming it makes sense and is explainable).  Additionally, I've always felt encouraged to make improvements in the process and tool chain wherever I see fit (and I've done so, repeatedly).  I've had "personal" projects I've done aiming to see if I could make something better turn into primary use tools for my team.  It's very satisfying to be in such an environment.
cons: Lack of organization.  Over abundance of consultants, and/or external development groups.  Lots of legacy systems being used in ways not originally intended, which leads to lots of shakey workarounds.

pros: Interesting style of menu and good presentation, I really enjoyed learning about the different events and menu items and fine dinning service.
cons: Slow business did not award a good overall experience. Though the food was interesting there was a lot of inconsistency resulting in inadequate training. The slow business did not help financial standings for my personal growth and the front house staff were not motivated to promote themselves. In other words, the standing around and gossiping was not a great 'training experience'. I did not stay for more than a month.

job_title: Reservation Sales Agent in Tampa, FL
pros: I have worked at Hilton almost 10 years.  I love having the flexibility and my own control of picking how many hours and days I work each week.  Being a working mom of three and still be able to participate at my childrens' school and be involved in all their extracurricular activities is the best of both worlds.  Hilton has afforded me the nicety of keeping my work identity and my mom identity.  Another great thing about Hilton is that they are always interested in feedback to continue the betterment of employee satisfaction.  They have a lot of employee incentives such as team member low hotel rates, contests, earning points and smiles that are equivalent to paid time off, paid holidays and retirement employer match just to name a few.
cons: I would have to say the downside to Hilton is they do not make it mandatory for me go to the gym even though they offer discounted gym memberships - LOL!

pros:
- The pay was nice.
- It was really peaceful when no one went to the pool or used the slide.
cons:
- Pool seemed kinda small to accommodate everyone. 
- Communication with management was poor. Definitely in need of some improvement
- There was this one puddle right in the middle of the deck that never went away (deck was uneven and water would not drain) so when there was a lit of people, obviously it would fill with water. Management always gave an unneccessary amount of time focusing on the water in the puddle than anything else
- Was accused of being on my phone during working hours after I had  it made it quite clear that my phone was not on my person
- Management is only happy if you decide to spend the rest of your life there. Was constantly asked why I wasn't working more hours and when given the reason why, they'd look at me like I was lazy

job_title: Regional Learning Manager in Watford, England
pros:
Too many to list in a review. Love working for Hilton. At the office, there are numerous initiatives each month to ensure we are well looked after. From complimentary massages, discounted Body Shop stuff, health MOTs, parties, free fruit, and a heavily subsidised Team Member restaurant, our Workplace Services team, along with senior executives all play their part to ensure we have a fantastic environment. 

Career progression opportunities are there and advertised internally for us to take advantage of. Training opportunities are fully laid out and emailed to every employee monthly, along with plentiful online resource. 

Hilton truly lives to its values and I love it.
cons: Sometimes, to get that next job, depending on what you're looking for, you'll either have to be patient, or be mobile to move across the country/world.

pros: I enjoy working there the other employees especially management are helpful and insightful. They truly care about keeping a positively charged atmosphere for all. I  was truly amazed at the sincerity of management in making me feel like a welcome addition to  the team.  This allowed me to consider seriously a long term commitment to this company because they are genuinely committed to there staff as well as customers .
cons: None . The scheduling is very flexible . Management are very down to earth , easy to talk to, and they address any concerns quickly and with care and attention to detail. I feel I can grow in this environment

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: The values of Hilton stand strong, and there is constant training from high above to better the company as a whole. Travel benefits are great also! Plenty of opportunity to grow with the company.
cons: The specific property I work at is a smaller one of <200 rooms, and there's pro's and cons to that factor. Biggest issue I have is when things need to get fixed, it takes weeks, sometimes months. We have a constant leak above the lobby, elevators are on and off, sometimes for weeks. We only have 2 Ice machines that work out of the 7 floors we have, there is mold growing on the ceiling in the back office, and we have residential toilets that overflow constantly, ruining our brand new renovated rooms, along with other various minor things that add up when a guest looks at our hotel specifically.

pros: I love coming to work! Hilton has always been known as innovative and that is something that drew me to them in the first place. The people are great which is so important in a work environment. The benefits are also a great perk.
cons: There are very few cons to this company. I would like to see more diversity at the leadership level. Our company preaches diversity and does a decent job of this but there is room for improvement. Diversity at the executive level is critical to capturing other customers. I would also say that compensation is a little lower as compared to market. The benefits are very good so I feel like it makes up for that.

review_title: There is no hospitality like understanding
job_title: Executive Sous Chef in London, England
pros: Let me take this opportunity to tell you how grateful I am to be working with Hilton What makes a workplace feel like home? It’s a place that brings out your best, every day. Because it makes you want to be better, every day. It’s a place where your strengths are appreciated. Where people welcome you as you are. And applaud you for where you’re going. It not only provides you with 'WEAR AND GEAR' to do the job. It also provides you the knowledge, support and training through HWWU. Discover the power of belonging. At Hilton, we feel it every day. It comes from being recognized. It comes from knowing Hilton sees talent in each of us. And, it comes from working together, as a family, to make our guests feel as much at home as we do.
cons: The wages a way to lower than market.

pros:
Staff discount. This is possibly one of the only positives. 

Some of the people you work with make your days worthwile
cons:
Management does not care about your progression or with helping you. There is this facade that you will progress if you follow the relevant courses and the typical norms within the company. It is much easier to look elsewhere for a role at the exact same level that will pay almost double the salary you would earn here. 

The concept of progression only applies to favourites and reviews are not completed for all team members. How is someone meant to progress if management has no idea what they are doing or refuses to acknowledge it?

pros: The reason I love Hilton is the people and the culture. Hilton has a great set of values and everyone takes them seriously from the lower level analysts to our CEO.  The mission of Hilton sharing the light and warmth of hospitality to all is not just talk.  The past few years have provided a number of new benefits and a focus on "Thriving" which has continued to make Hilton a better and better place to work.
cons: There are always a lot of delicious treats around the office so you really have to watch your waist line.

pros: Hilton is the best hospitality company I have ever worked before. You feel you are part of a huge family with wonderful people from different cultures around the world. Hilton gave me the opportunity to grow as a professional as we have multiple and constant trainnings as well as leadership programs to develop and excel our carrer. We do have real leaders that guide us and mentor us constantly. You will never be bored... they have several ways to motivate the team members and makes us fell we really care, spreading the values and magic of hospitality. We also have lots of benefits as the Go Hilton program so you can travel around the world with stunning offerts. You need it to make it happen once in your life to feel the real taste of working for such an amazing company!
cons: Things you can expect from hospitality, as extra hours depending on the shift, etc. All you have to do is work with passion.

job_title: Reservations and Customer Care in Hazleton, PA
pros: The medical benefit package isn't too bad.
cons: Their policies and procedures prevent you from succeeding.  They hire you to do a job, but then their policies and proceedures prevent you from doing it.   Vacation days are very difficult to schedule,  and consecutive days off are nearly impossible to get.  And unless you have many years of seniority, you will never spend a holiday at home with your family.  Their attendance policy is a bit unrealistic, especially for those with children.

review_title: Great culture and company but has its flaws
pros:
- Great PTO policy - 5 weeks right off the bat
- Team Member rate is decent, able to get discounted hotel rooms during off peak season
- Great team culture, there are often many team member events from pizza day, food truck day and movie screenings.
cons:
- Small teams which result in long hours
- Very cliquey and gossipy environment - Certain Directors and VPs dominate all decisions/conversations and is more about who you know than the actual work.
- Open seating environment. Directors and below all sit in an open seating, and no one wants to talk on the phone or talk to each other out loud because it is distracting to others and no one has any privacy.
-Working from home because of the open seating environment is frowned upon.

job_title: Manager, Project Support in Addison, TX
pros:
Work life balance is really important to the employer, forward career advancement is encouraged, transferring to different departments is allowed and encouraged,  quarterly employee recognition events, family environment,   on the job training, work from home once a week, team member travel discounts (family and friends included) for anywhere around the world, the salary is comparable or greater then other revenue companies, job security, discounts on mattresses and other misc items, 401 k match, benefits are awesome: dental, medical, vision, met law, etc. 

Really my time at Hilton has been a blessing and feel so strongly about the company, that I recommend this company to all my friends.
cons: Currently there are no stock options offered to team members. Sometimes the work can be tedious.

pros: Lots of diverse opportunities both in location and roles. If you're willing to try new things, sky's the limit here. We also have great people - its hard to find people more passionate for their company than Hilton employees! They LOVE Hilton! We also know how to have fun too, which never hurts. My favorite part of working at Hilton though is the ability to push really big, impact, innovative projects - if you build a solid business case, you can almost always find a way to get it done which is very unique.
cons: As with any big, global company, you need a lot of approvals and buy-in to move projects forward. This isn't a negative but just a reality of the job. With the right attitude it is fine, but some people get frustrated by this aspect.

review_title: Being employed by Hilton Worldwide was very reward and fulfilling. In my opinion it's the best hotel in the Industry.
job_title: Front Desk Or Night Auditor in Killeen, TX
pros: Team Member involvement. Room for advancement. Great insurance and travel benefits. Ability to have autonomy in the workplace. Team member empowerment on guest issues. The travel perks are amazing with employee rooms as little as $29.
cons: Depends on the hotel's management. If the place is organized, then it's amazing. If the GM and leaders in the hotel aren't organized, if they disagree, etc., then your experience will not be as great. Goes the same for any company. In leadership roles, you are expected to work much longer hours and will wear all hats in the hotel, qualified or not.

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Carrollton, TX
pros: You get paid every two weeks. You get to stay at the hotel maybe once during your time at the company.
cons: Guest Assistant Department is the worse department in the WORLD. Management will try to figure out a way out of giving you a raise after a year of working in the call center and taking over 250 calls a week. Employee turnover is welcomed by management since they would rather not keep you at the company. During training, they try to convince you it is a great company, knowing you may not be there for only two or three months. People start getting fired after 6 weeks to 2 months. The policies change every week, One supervisor will give you recommendations to improve, then they switch supervisors on you after two months. They new supervisor will give you information inconsistent from your last supervisor. You can never get ahead at this company. This position should be considered as a temporary position. You will never enjoy working here. Get your money after one month and run.

job_title: HRCC Customer Service Representative in Hattiesburg, MS
pros:
Great Company Culture 
Benefits/Paid Time Off and Sick Emergency Time
Perks of reduced room rates at Hilton Locations
The Option to Build Your Schedule
cons:
The pay is not in line with what a Customer Service rep should be making which is why I left the company for one that does pay what a rep should be earning.
Building Your Schedule is a disaster. System freezes up, you will miss out on the hours you want. 
Work Life Balance is not flexible due to the issues with Building Your Schedule.
Systems experience way too many outages leaving a negative experience for your customer you are on the line with and you can't help them because of that.

review_title: GC&E sales executive pro actively bring business into the hotel including meetings, events and even accommodation.
pros:
I work for Hilton as they are a brilliant company especially our hotel! always making sure the staff are happy and enjoying there time here, Hilton has made me build a career within hospitality by giving me the opportunity to start off as concierge to get my experience in and around the hotel, gaining guest skills an making a better me.

Then i have been promoted to sales, iv always wanted to do sales but never had the experience and the knowledge to do so, so i shown the hotel i can do it and they gave me a shot at the role, i relay am enjoying my work place always positive team moral and a brilliant place to work with extremely good management and staff members.
cons: no cons in the hotel at all, i have had no problems and Hilton is progressing my career every second of the day.

review_title: Can be great. Can also be absolutely terrible.
pros: Great employee benefits - a lot of discount on hotel rooms, some members of staff are fantastic and some management, good variety of skills to learn and lots of courses you can go on etc if your manager is good.
cons: It’s all about location. I’ve been at 2 Hilton properties, the first was amazing, staff were like a family, GM was very friendly and open and approachable. Second property (and the reason I left), the owners of the property had too much say and the whole place was about nothing but money. Upper management didn’t care about any staff regardless of the fact staff turnover was so high. No Hilton values whatsoever. Pay is not good in the U.K. for the work you do and obviously any front of house Role, the shifts are all over the place.

review_title: You'll like it at first, but quickly outgrow it
job_title: Associate Software Developer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
Good team atmosphere
Flexible working hours 
Remote working whenever you like
cons:
Tech stack: (Wordpress, PHP, JQuery)

Pay: Be prepared to work for terrible pay. If management could get away with paying you £1 an hour, they would. So don't bother to look for a raise at any point. If you want more money, you'll need to look for another job.

If you're coming straight from higher education e.g. college, uni - this job isn't a bad job. You'll get experience, for sure. (Which is what everyone is dying to get) - However, if you're an ambitious Developer, constantly looking to skill-up, and work with the latest and greatest...you'll soon find yourself stagnating after the first 6 months. 

The skills you'll walk away with are VERY basic. So, if you've not been studying in your own time, be prepared to be unprepared for what the industry is looking for in terms of skills and experience. Because this job wont give you that.

review_title: Promise a lot, deliver little - Hilton Focus Service Division
pros: Reporting, tools, marketing.  Resources that help you do the job.  Autonomy in most positions but left to learn on your own (pro & con).
cons: Absence of Senior Management and leadership.  Unfairness in work place, with inconsistent policies and shortcuts.  Credit was wrongfully awarded in a corporate/boss mentality of reflecting responsibility - toxic work environment.  They sell advancement in company however it is hard to come by unless the right people move on.  Prefer to view employees as factors of productivity rather than investing in good people.  Salary and bonus structure de-incentivizing - based on gates above 100% but 120% means the same as 101%.  High turnover due to low salary and budget restraints.  Work life balance is difficult to maintain - always need to be available.

pros: Working from home in your PJ's is a nice perk. The Travel Discounts are incredible and they recently improved it providing food discounts up to 50% at some properties. When traveling you during personal time you have 12 brands to choose from so you can always find something.
cons: The network issues working from home can be a nightmare, The system is dated. They are trying to make improvements but they still have many more to make. I have seen small improvements but the logistics of handling so many types of hardware configurations makes it a slow process and could take many more years than they would hope.

review_title: Excellent company to have a career with!
job_title: Front Desk Supervisor in Orlando, FL
pros: There are lots of opportunities and resources to grow in the company, Hilton offers outstanding benefits to its employees from great health benefits to various discounts, all your hard work is recognized and management takes the time to built a development plan and shape you up to better succeed in your career with Hilton and the pay is good (some properties like mine offer commission on top of your check which is a big plus).
cons: After you retire with Hilton you don't get to keep your hotel discounts.

review_title: Hilton Hotel was burning me out
job_title: Food & Beverage Director in London, England
pros: To make my resume looks good is probably the only reason I could think of after I left there. Thought the Hilton brand contained good reputation and high standard though.
cons:
1. Unordinary long working time without reasonable payment
2. Unbalanced work/life management, often get call back on off-work days
3. Security issues, employees' lockers been stolen many times
4. Reward system is not clear and fair, hard to attract employees to involve

review_title: Great salary/benefits, but the department needs some work
pros:
- fair compensation
- great benefits
- cheap travel
- lots of leisure time during work
- mostly great people
- looks good on your resume
cons:
- directors have poor understanding of what our jobs are or how they should accurately be measured
- lack of access to data needed to optimize our sites
- judged on driving revenue but not given enough autonomy to make strategic decisions on how to drive thay revenue
- hostility and distrust between senior managers and directors prevents positive change
- portfolio sizes are too large making it difficult to adapt during times of high turnover
- leadership let's slackers slide while overloading their good people for extended periods of time
- yearly survey is taken, but nothing changes

review_title: Such a shame that a leading hotel brand has the worst leadership in the industry
pros: Hilton has 13 great brands and excellent talent at the manager - mid manager level, they just cant seem to get their senior leadership right and will always fall short compared to Marriott. I loved the work and my actual job their, but every manager I had in 4 years were complete disasters and totally unqualified.
cons: The biggest con about Hilton is that no matter how smart or talented you are it really doesn't matter.  Most people move up at Hilton by sleeping with executive leadership not because of good performance. It really is such a shame.  Leadership is the #1 pitfall at Hilton and one of the main reasons why Marriott eat them for breakfast, always getting to market before Hilton with a new idea.

pros:
One of the main reasons I've stayed with Hilton as long as I have (>20 years) is the flexibility I've been afforded. I've been able to work from home full-time since 1999, and have flexed my hours a number of times as we started having children; our schedule would change every two years or so, and my boss was willing to work with me on solutions.
The other main reason I love it here is the people. I'm sure it's related to being in the hospitality industry, but everyone is simply very nice and eager to serve (as opposed to always wanting to be served). The relationships I've formed here are genuine and meaningful.
cons: Although it's a positive that expectations are high, the work load can be quite heavy and even overwhelming at times. I don't like to let people down, so that has been my greatest challenge for the past few years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Abu Dhabi, Abu Dhabi
pros: Working at Hilton is such an honor to me, my great expectation has been met and there’s a lot more of opportunity at hand it is an opportunity where I have to grab, nurture and claim as my success to career.  For me Hilton is not just an industry of providing hospitality; Hilton it is a growing global family where shaping their staff to be at its greater success in this industry.
cons: I don’t have any negative to tell to Hilton, but I know every hotel has its difficulties and negative side but here in Hilton we have the best management doing best to cope up difficulties. It is good to know that we have the right communication, the management communicates the staff well, and transparency is trusted.
