For me Hilton is not just an industry of providing hospitality; Hilton it is a growing global family where shaping their staff to be at its greater success in this industry.
cons: I don’t have any negative to tell to Hilton, but I know every hotel has its difficulties and negative side but here in Hilton we have the best management doing best to cope up difficulties. It is good to know that we have the right communication, the management communicates the staff well, and transparency is trusted.

review_title: Traditionally good company to work for
pros: Hilton is offering you the opportunity to learn and develop yourself through training organised inside the department by your supervisors/managers and by the human resources department who will make you understand the company culture much better
cons: On the other hand worth mentioning cons would be the salary which is in line with the industry and overall is not great for entry-level but it increases as you climb up the ladder. Resources are at the brand standard level but the company can lag behind others in terms of new technologies which can make both your and the guests life easier

job_title: Human Resource Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: One HUGE pro is the perk of staying at a Hilton Hotel at a discounted rate, this is amazing and widely used.  Travel the world and stay at an Embassy Suites for as little as $39.00 a night!  But this is far from the only perk available.
cons: I cannot think of any direct cons toward Hilton.  A Hilton can be corporate, franchised or privately owned so there is no need to worry about the stuffy corporate feel or small town private feel, an employee can choose what fits their needs.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits, 401K, There is nothing else!
cons: No flexibility, terrible computer system and telephone systems, constantly dropping calls in the middle of a reservation which affects you numbers which affect your pay. Management does absolutely nothing but ride you about your productivity, they don't care if the lines go down and the starting wage is horrible. I made more when I was a teenager. Don't even think about wanting to change your schedule, not happening. Oh, and they would rather you send the customer to the timeshare department, another free lead. If you don't, on every call, you are documented and fired. I thought they wanted to book rooms, but you don't get paid on that, you get an override on the transfers. So stupid! Chris Nassetta, the President should be fired, ashamed he went to UVA, I am from Virginia originally!

pros:
Benefits:  healthcare, free/discounted hotel rooms.  OT and work performance incentive: you earn points and smiles which you can buy PTO hours, gifts cards and lunch vouchers with.
Friendly work environment.   There's lots of opportunities to move within the company.
cons:
Maximum raise you can receive after a good annual performance evaluation is 0.50.  It is a must that you love customer service to do this type of work because the job does not pay you enough to listen to guests complain (some are valid and some are from guests who just take advantage of the system to get a free room) all day long.  
it's almost impossible to get PTO/s approved during holidays and summer months not unless you apply months in advance to get an approval.

review_title: Professional work environment that empowers the employees with chances to make immediate day to day decisions.
pros: The employees make working here a great experience. It's a legitimate family atmosphere and it's difficult to not have immediate support from any department for any situation. The guest is everyone's priority. Amazing benefits. Great working environment. Good hours. Attentive managers, and a solid fundamental system for upward movement within the company.
cons: The pay is average. I can't knock the company for paying the standard wages set in our economy, but it's still difficult to make ends meet without taking every overtime opportunity that pops up. Very taxing on maintaining healthy family interactions. It is what it is though.

pros: Hours always available... that's it.
cons: Where to start? Minimum wage to do hard physical work and be treated terribly. Any tips I earned were small and sometimes stolen by my coworkers. Not only were the guests often jerks, my coworkers were downright mean sometimes. I was physically attached by my coworker cause I wanted to start on the next day's work since we had finished the night's work early. They made her go to counseling but she didn't even have to apologize. My managers outright said they would fire anyone who called out on a weekend (no matter the reason) or who didn't come in when called in even if they gave no notice. The break room was disgusting and covered in flies. My managers encouraged me to skip my breaks saying stuff like "Good employees put their work first" etc. My friend was fired for insubordination after she told them they had no right to ask her to skip breaks. They made me sign a non-disclosure agreement... But I could just go on and on.

review_title: Great benefits, not so great management culture
job_title: Non-Voice Guest Services in Houston, TX
pros: The benefits are fantastic, although my medical insurance costs keep increasing. They are generous with the PTO and sick time, and they were very considerate during Harvey (I work from home). They also have great discounts for hotel rates if you want to stay in the hotels.
cons: Middle management is monolithic and won't budge when it comes to anything outside what you do. Want to improve a process? Report a coworker failing to do what they're supposed to do? Too bad. You'll just have to bite the bullet and keep working. It is a stressful job if you crave order, efficiency, and accountability, but if you're just out to get a paycheck, it would probably work for you. As mentioned previously, my insurance keeps increasing every year, which is difficult to accept when senior management repeatedly emails everyone about how much money the company made. Lateral promotions are also quite rare.

pros: Many events put on for employees; can be a very reasonable number of hours depending on the department you work in. A lot of good people at the rank and file level, both in terms of competence and work ethic. Growing number of prominent women in management.
cons: Some departments have terrible hours. Leadership / managers not always very good. Compensation is not terribly strong. Politics present, like every major company. Growing number of arrogant MBA types that have more influence than hospitality veterans that have no idea what happens on the ground and don't care - and leaders that would rather listen to them since the company now answers to Wall Street. Limited opportunities for advancement. Virtually no diversity in upper management except for gender diversity.

pros: Hilton is a strong company that cares about it's employees and their work/life balance.  In our department, there are flexible hours, great benefits for full time employees, a chance to move up in the company, and a sense of family.
cons: As with all large corporate companies, there are some drawbacks.  compensation for bonuses and incentives are still a work in progress and have a way to go.  As large as we are, after going public 2 years ago, we still do not have any stock options for middle and lower management or hourly staff.

pros:
Hilton is such a great company to work for, the opportunities I have been given in the last five years are truly amazing. 
I have worked up from a Food and Beverage Apprentice to Account Executive and have experienced so many one in a life time opportunities along the way. 
Due to the training and investment that I have received over the years I won highly commended for both the Rising Star Awards and also the Apprentice Awards. 
I have also visited so many countries that I would have never had the chance to visit not having special team member rates or gone there for work.
cons: I do not have any cons.

review_title: No Development in the "Development Coach", job is to let the resv. know only what they do wrong, not motivating at all
job_title: Reservations Work From Home in Dallas, TX
pros: Flexibility in hours, Hotel discounts, work from home, Dallas Reservations.
cons: Not motivating at all, all you hear is what your doing wrong every time you hear from supervisor or "DC", monthly bonus is almost impossible and depends on luck of the calls not your actions.  I lost my job due to being sick and running out of emergency time.  The dc was out to get rid of me and found a loop of 3 write ups/yr.  I had one month out of 56 that I did not meet the 95% attendance and lost my job.

review_title: Good Benefits and great job if you have the right manager
pros: Benefits are amazing, ample PTO, employee discount program that can be shared with family and friends, great 401k match,  telecommute ability depending on position held
cons: Thrive - Work/Life balance program does not apply to all. Some management is not on board with the company wide program and still have old school mentality that if they can't eyeball you then you are not working,

pros: Hilton is a place where you can achieve your career goals. You only need to be willing to learn and have the motivation with you and Hilton will take your career to the level of your dreams. Hilton gives you all the tools you need for your development. It is a company that really cares about the employees, not only regarding their career growth but as well they worklife balance. In this company there is a true commitment to encorage Team Members to be happy in their workplace. As part of the Human Resources team, that is my everyday duty. Personally I've grow a lot since I'm in Hilton and I only regret to not join Hilton earlier in my career.
cons: There is nothing I can  realistic say that it is negative.

pros: I have been at one of Hilton's corporate offices for almost a year now and I love my job. My coworkers are friendly and passionate about their work and my managers are fair and understanding. There is a lot of flexibility in hours and we are able to work from home once a week. We are constantly thinking of new ways to improve, which keeps our work fresh and exciting. I receive nearly a month of paid vacation time per year and incredible discounts on hotels, which I am now using to travel and live the Hilton values.
cons: Entry level pay, however I am looking forward to growth within the company and the pay that will come with it.

job_title: Night Auditor in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Working for Hilton has been a great Experience, from the team members from the management to our wonderful Guest. Hilton is an ideal work place for people who are looking to grow as a family, Learning and most important Delivering 100 percent to our Wonderful Guest.  Hilton gives you the opportunity to grow within which is a great benefit to your career and life skills.  Hilton Values every Guest every Employee which is the reason why I love working for Hilton...
cons: Working for Hilton has taught me how to turn Cons To Pros..  Which is why I live by the Values, The Vision is Clear and im on the Mission by creating heartfelt experiences for Guests, meaningful opportunities for Team Members, high value for Owners and a positive impact in our Communities.  thank you Hilton your Night Auditor..

pros: Hours are ok and freindly coworkers, close to home
cons: AlwayS put on a guilt trip if decline any extra hours , management treat workers very poorly, laziness everywhere and very understaffed and hectic. Manegment cussing at employees and disreapectful Very unfocused and everything is always rushed. Told we have the most staff over other hotels but yet never have any help. Very frustrating when everybody can opt out of doing task by calling it another term so a different department can assess . Very unfair. And management will play favorites. THIS PLACE IS CRUMBLING DOWN! Every room has issues every day from neglect and utter laziness. So many rooms for just one person to fix. One maintanance man running calls and playing catch up all day long because of  10 minute time limits.  I advise only working here for the expierience then move on.

review_title: Poor senior management team who are becoming very wealthy from the efforts of people for which they have little regard.
pros: The company pays pretty well, and some of the people you work with on a day-to-day basis are pretty good. The location is great for those that live North of London , Oxford, or South Midlands. There are frequent team off-sites, which are a lot of fun, but they do not really make up for the daily pain of just trying to do get your job done.
cons: The management team and the politics within departments make working there a very frustrating experience. If you are chosen for support and promotion, and play the game with senior management, then advancement is possible. If you don't mind selling your soul for a wage, then you can certainly may steady progress through the ranks.

job_title: Gift Shop Attendant in Orlando, FL
pros: Team member travel program is decent (as long as what you are looking for is available), pay is pretty good; as a gift shop attendant I started at $9.00/hr and now I make almost $10/hr. Friendly managers.
cons: Weekend scheduling (at least in my department) is a joke. Only one person working the gift shop for the whole day on any given Saturday or Sunday. Makes for a super long, boring, and challenging shift if it is a busy day. Also, have tried numerous times to advance and have been passed over for someone less qualified. I'm at the point of giving up any hope of starting a decent career with this company.

job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Bournemouth, England
pros: Great team, fast paced environment, never a dull day.  Great name for a CV. Some managers could be quite fun!
cons:
Management seem completely incompetent at times, they don't seem capable of recognising the hard workers from the lazy staff, resulting in everyone getting shouted at. 

No planning is in place when rotas are made and every shift is unorganised. At minimum wage it should not be up to operational staff to delegate sections and tasks to each other, however with no leadership from bosses, we have to! 

Very little recognition when you go above and beyond in your role which can lead to frustration and makes you start to think 'why should I even bother'.

review_title: Hilton delivers on its employee satisfaction
job_title: Director of Commercial Services in Atlanta, GA
pros: To start, Hilton gets the basics right from benefits like insurance, 401K, PTO with options and choices to select what is best for the individual team member.  Hilton consistently tries to enhance the work experience with refreshed team member break areas, competitions to win awards and the best travel incentive plans. That way team members can get away and still afford to go anywhere in the world.
cons: If you work in the hotel industry or have in the past, the bulk of opportunities to work at a Hilton (or Family Branded) hotel means you are working for a franchise property and usually some form of a management company.  I have done both, and working for Hilton directly at a Hilton Corporate managed hotel is definitely the way to go.

review_title: One of the Best corporate jobs I've had.
job_title: Front Office Supervisor in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: No one feels like it is above or below them when it comes to completing or handling a task. Management is really supportive and backs you when you have a guest issue. Travel benefits are AMAZING. Roughly $40 a night at most higher end hilton owned properties, when available. Health benefits are very nice as well. A lot of opportunity to move around within as well. Upper management like to take in feed back from the people on the lower end of the pay scale.
cons: Gossip, like any work place, can get out of hand. Other than that, I cannot complain too much about this company.

review_title: Front Desk Gets NO HELP and Management is the WORST
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Glendale, CA
pros: Stable and set schedule. Discounted hotel room rates, health benefits, 401 K, and  free lunch during shifts.
cons: It is the busiest during the weekend and there is never a manager around to relieve the stress. When we have a manager on duty, they don't know anything about how the Front Desk works. Management says the employees have to understand that the Front Desk is not their department. What is the point of an MOD if they don't even understand the basics of how each department works? Management claims that all employees are also "empowered" to do whatever they have to do resolve the issue but be aware, if you do they will get mad at you soon after. They will harass you VIA text message and be very rude without hearing you out. We are SO short staffed and have been for over 6 months, now. Every single time we have important events... Nothing is ever done right. Most careless place I have every worked at!

pros: Working as a Development Coach at Hilton Reservations and Customer Care is a very dynamic, ever changing position.  Being the direct supervisor of a virtual sales team is exciting, rewarding and challenging all at once!  If you like a fast-paced environment, working with people with various backgrounds and personalities - this is a fantastic job!  You have the ability to be creative and present sales coaching feedback in a supportive working environment.  Hilton also takes a strong belief in managing an equal work-life balance which is greatly important to me.
cons: Because the role of a Development Coach is always evolving - there are often a lot of changes that take place.  Sometimes it can take awhile for a new process to become implemented and routine.

review_title: Hilton needs to take care of the employees that take care ot guests
job_title: Senior Event Manager in Houston, TX
pros: If someone does not have a higher education, with a lot of hard work, anyone is able to become management.  However, while you are working your way up, the company will take advantage of you.
cons:
Low pay for management team compared to local competition.  Upper Management does not promote "team" spirit.  There is a lack of making employees feel as the are important to the company.  Even the HR Director has made the comment that if an employee does not like policy, then they can work somewhere else.
The work/life balance is nonexistant.  Upper management rather run the current employees into the ground before hiring additional staff.

review_title: Hiltion, A great place to to work
pros: The Memphis corporate office has a comfortable, casual workplace that makes you happy to come to work in the morning. When your life requires you to be elsewhere, the work schedule can be flexible as long as you work something out with your manager. The benefits are good ranging from your typical 401(k) plan and a solid medical program to discounts on hotel rooms and hotel furnishings.
cons:
Office politics can be a drag but I suppose that will be an issue wherever you go. I also assume this will vary from place to place you work within Hilton.
Hilton is not an IT company, and the IT department does not run as such. If you are used to and prefer structure and standards, you may be dissapointed.

pros: co workers were competent,,, it has a low employee turnover rate,,, some have been there for 7 years or more, The clientele is consistent, for that reason, so is the pay in tipped positions.  Management is fair for the most part and is very understanding in cases of family or personal issues.  Possibility of working other positions in the hotel or restaraunt guarantees at least 40 hours per week.
cons: location,, canonsburg is a bit out of the way.  Management tier is confusing.. 1 G.M. ,,, 2 managers, 1 asst mangager, 2 shift leaders... hard to get all on the same page.  VERY hard to get a promotion there

review_title: Very poor especially when compared to other similar employers
job_title: Conference and Events Sales Executive in Aberdeen, Scotland
pros: Working for a well known brand looks great on the CV, benefits and the people were great, however the benefits could be difficult to access.
cons: Lack of support, high expectations and lack of communication from senior management when there are problems. Size of a very inexperienced team halved then they wondered why standards slipped after offering little - no support, then making a fairly junior member of staff responsible for it all without supporting her in improving. Working so many hours on such a poor salary meant that by going over salaried wage (40 hours) by just 5 hours a week dropped salary below minimum wage threshold - 50 hour weeks were not unusual. Agreed lieu time was then difficult to redeem due to workload.

job_title: Host in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Your first week working for this company really sets the standard.  It was unlike anything else.  Everyone at Hilton truly loves working for this company, the moral and attitudes of everyone there are evidence to that.  Walking through the halls everyone greets you and acknowledges you like you've been friends for years.  It's not something to take for granted.  The clientele are wonderful, they're usually traveling from other states or even countries and they're always so polite and kind, the culture that surrounds this place is a one of a kind experience.
cons: Management seems to just repeat mistakes and wonder why nothing is being changed, or why they're seeing the same results.

pros: Having a variety of Hilton Brands and Properties that meet every guests' needs. Great employee discounted rates at Hilton properties.  The training class allowed some flexibility in your schedule.  Outside of the specified times for the Virtual Instructor Led Training classes and role play, it was self-paced so you could arrange that time the way you needed to as long as you completed your modules.
cons: There were glitches with the training modules that caused some people to not complete training.  Employees did not have an opportunity to speak with management to explore their options, such as transferring to  another training class; they were just terminated.

review_title: Great brands and nice people but stressful due to lack of direction
pros:
- Stable, globally recognized brands
- Ambitious international growth strategy
- Friendly people from diverse backgrounds
- Young org with opportunity to define roles and find new ways of doing things
cons:
- There is no old way of doing things - the focus on redefining process and decision rights stifles creativity and strategic thinking in everyday work
- Leadership fails to focus and communicate unified strategies causing everyone to work towards different objectives
- Stressful environment where everyone seems overworked without results

pros: Hilton is a great company to grow, there are basically unlimited options when it comes to positions and locations too. They have quite a good training scheme and will try to support in your growth. Since the employee turnover is insanely high, the promotions are coming quite quickly. The Elevator program is a great thing!
cons: Everything depends on your manager. When the manager is good, they will make your life easier. When is incompetent they will make your life living hell. You have to fight for everything, but if you are able to do so, you might eventually get somewhere. Oh and of course, as almost everywhere else in the hospitality industry, the money is ridiculous.

pros: The company offers great Team Member benefits and sets a big focus on career development. People who are interested in an international career get all the tools and support from the company to achieve their career goals. Learning & Development is a key strength of the brand and attracts many talents. Someone has the opportunity to get to know people from all over the world as the work force is very diverse which helps you not to only develop your communication skills but also broaden your intercultural competences. Your team is like a family. Everyone supports each other and that's very important for people who spend most of their time at work.
cons: There are many standards that every department has to comply with which makes it sometimes difficult to change things. Also the compensation is not very much which makes it very difficult sometimes to hire the right people.

review_title: Horrible treatment and management. Great customer service development.
job_title: Guest Service Agent in San Gabriel, CA
pros: Great way to develop customer service skills. The interaction you get with every guest is very personal so over time it will improve your communication skills.
cons: Horrible management. Too many politics for a small 4 star hotel. Unfair treatment for newcomers and the upper levels are biased to employees with higher seniority. I can understand if those with seniority have more leeway in certain things, however, it shouldn't be in everything. For example, when it came to scheduling and taking long breaks, employees that stayed longer were allowed to have their requests fulfilled. But if you are not there for long enough, even if you are the same title, you can't even request an early leave because you are feeling unwell (even with a doctor's note provided next day). Instead you will get interrogated like no tomorrow. Unbelievable. If you don't mind being mistreated like a tool, then feel free to work here.

pros: At Hilton I feel as part of a family. The company is paying a lot of attention on the employees, and it is very easy to make a career if you have the right skills and attitude, as the options are very wide due to the number of existing and future properties. As a team member, you and your personal life is taken into consideration and there is always support from the company if the situation requires.
cons:
To stay on top, there is a lot of work to do, therefore finding time for personal life can be challenging, but with a proper organization, this can be achieved. Nevertheless, the results of your hard work are visible.
Not so many team building for the Management, and also not so many team buildings at the division level.

review_title: If you are interested in hospitality, this is for you!
pros: This is a good place to work if you are interested in the hospitality industry. Hilton is all about customer satisfaction and going above and beyond the call of duty and I have experienced this at other Hilton hotels/brands so it isn't just at certain hotels. They are the best when it comes to training.
cons: I think this is a con of working with most busy hotels, but there is tension (between co-workers and departments) when the hotel gets really busy. No one really wants to make a mistake or take blame when a mistake is mistaken.

job_title: Reservation Sales Representative in El Paso, TX
pros: Hilton offers an extremely flexible program for selecting your own schedule. For somebody who is balancing work and school this is extremely useful. There are also very good opportunities for commission if you are a high performer. Travel benefits are amazing! It is often very fun to help people plan their trips. Hilton definitely does value its employees and there are very clear avenues to voice feedback to the company, and they do listen and adjust as they can.
cons: Base pay is a little low to start, about 10-20% lower than similar jobs in the area.  Employee discounts can sometimes be a bit difficult to use.

review_title: Great PTO and hotel rate benefits
job_title: Guest Service Agent in Dallas, TX
pros:
-You earn PTO as you go and can use PTO hours whenever you'd like throughout your career (i.e. a trip or vacation, paid off-day)
-You have many discounted rates available to you to travel anywhere you'd like at 35, 45, 55, or 75 usd/night along with a fast-track-to-gold benefit that will get you hotel perks and benefits such as comp. breakfast or executive lounge access at the hotels you choose to stay with.
cons: As a GSA, the hours can be early in the morning, in the middle of the day, or late at night and you'll never know when you'll be working. Very difficult to maintain a regular schedule. At the Hilton properties I've worked for in the past, front office management releases the schedules only a few days before the start date of that schedule. Very difficult to make plans, doctor's appointments, etc.

pros: Company has a great reputation, lots of different areas you can move around in if you are not satisfied where you are.
cons: At the location I was at it was very hectic and disorganized work environment. Also slightly hostile at certain times. Very long shifts with a lot of walking. Outfits are long sleeve dark blue polyester with black pants and long black aprons - and we had to wait tables outside - extremely uncomfortable in the humidity and heat.

job_title: Supervisor in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: You meet great customers and great people.
cons:
I don't know where to start from...
-The staff food is absolutely awful and it's usually just chips! 
-The management cares only about profits and that is it... No staff recognition or anything like that... You can be better than anyone you will still get nothing extra and sometimes get pushed because you are the one that can work a lot.
-For a supervising position you get 5% more than a casual worker (minimum wage)
-None of the higher managers care about what customers think and feel, all they care is about the numbers and that is it.
-No one in the entire hotel know anything about the Hilton standards or anything like that because 60% of the people in there are totally incompetent.
-I don't know how come Hilton Worldwide lets this hotel be operational... (there are so many complaints that come from the customers and no one cares)
-It would be better for someone to work in a corner restaurant than this hotel.

job_title: Supervisor in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: You meet great customers and great people.
cons:
I don't know where to start from...
-The staff food is absolutely awful and it's usually just chips! 
-The management cares only about profits and that is it... No staff recognition or anything like that... You can be better than anyone you will still get nothing extra and sometimes get pushed because you are the one that can work a lot.
-For a supervising position you get 5% more than a casual worker (minimum wage)
-None of the higher managers care about what customers think and feel, all they care is about the numbers and that is it.
-No one in the entire hotel know anything about the Hilton standards or anything like that because 60% of the people in there are totally incompetent.
-I don't know how come Hilton Worldwide lets this hotel be operational... (there are so many complaints that come from the customers and no one cares)
-It would be better for someone to work in a corner restaurant than this hotel.

pros: Free breakfast, Low prices to book at other Hilton properties
cons: Lack of management on property. You can be fired without any counseling/write up.  No benefits. No lunch break but 30min lunch deducted from pay. Low pay. No advancement opportunities. High employee turnover rate. No overtime pay. (even if you worked over it is taken from your check!) No set schedule (what time you come to work may be changed without your consent.)

review_title: Director of Events and Catering Sales
job_title: Director, Events & Catering in Chicago, IL
pros: Here in Hilton, I work with talented team members who are passionate about making a difference, serving guests directly and in directly and all the while-learning and having fun. We work smarter, not harder. And when you have a role that is not "work"-every day is an exciting adventure. I/we grow professionally and personally. Hilton Benefits are a great value too.  To be candid, I love what I do. This is the next best business to show business.  And for me-"the future's so bright-I gotta wear shades."
cons: I have no concerns/issues with Hilton Hotels and it's core values.  Each year, Hilton is recognized as a great Company to work for and be a part of in this ever changing industry.

review_title: This Is A Customer Service Position.
pros: Work from home. My team was mostly professional and nice.
cons: Very disappointing experience. During my recruitment, with deep experience managing large marketing budgets & campaigns, I was sold the dream of shot-calling larger campaigns with the downside of limited client-facing duties. Upon arrival, I was horrified to learn that this is just an overpaid customer service job. "Managers" don't even have access to basic analytics, much less coming anywhere near touching a campaign or making a decision. The folks running the department showed little regard for work-life boundaries, and were not the most direct or tact communicators. A bit cheap for a large organization. "Working from home" was actually more of a requirement than a benefit. Could've shown a little more class when I did finally find a way out.

pros: Various schedules available, Good values, recognized brands and company with a global footprint.  Great products, travel benefits and good training.  Located conveniently in Carrollton Texas.....close to Addison, Dallas, Farmers Branch and other suburbs.
cons: Good values on paper only  - Terrible culture (Good old boys club) It's really who you know and kiss up to that matters  - not how good you are.  Contact center is rife with politics, corruption and manipulation of metrics by various means such as outages, call gating, guest survey score and quality assurance data manipulation etc.

review_title: Hilton Worldwide is the best company to work for! There are so many opportunities for career growth.
job_title: Assistant Front Office Manager in Cape Town
pros: My ideas are valued. I am trusted by my superiors. I have a great Leadership Team. I have met the best Leaders in Hospitality at the Hilton Worldwide Properties I have had the privilege to work for. Hilton brings out the best in me. Hilton cares for their employees. There are great recognition programs in place. The Hilton Worldwide University is an awesome learning channel.There are great travel opportunities available for work and leisure on Go-Hilton.
cons: Like any big company, you need to create your own success. It is just easier with Hilton.

pros: Hilton provides amazing travel benefits! If you love to explore the world, the travel benefits alone are worth being employed by Hilton because not only do they offer heavy discounts on hotels but they also provide employees with enough PTO to take advantage of that perk, while encouraging team members to use all their accumulated days. The eCommerce team members are great to work with. Everyone is helpful, friendly, and fun! Lastly, the company is growing like crazy which will hopefully bring new career growth opportunities.
cons: Very Corporate--since going public, (naturally) Hilton has become very results driven and has lost sight on some of the primary hospitality fundamentals. Results are a top priority when companies go public so it's understandable. Lastly, health insurance is pretty expensive--but they do offer tons of providers to help you choose the best option for you/your family.

pros: The atmosphere is great! The people I work with are great. The pay is good, the benefits are ok at best, and the partys when given have the best food. I feel safe as the location is nice and there is security around the clock.
cons: The games management plays when it comes down to our situation with the coming layoffs. They get us all together to basically say "your head might get chopped but you will not know for 30 more days". This is not fair to all the employees. Our moral is shot. Plainly shot. There was a time when people walked around laughing but now the building is quiet. It is sad when you see your own boss in fear of whats to come.

pros: The best thing about Hilton is their benefits package. From what I have heard hilton has the best team member travel plan but on the flip side there is no holiday pay. All resorts are open 365, but I do remember it in the late 90's they had holiday so it looks like the employees traded this for that.
cons: Hilton is one of the largest hotel chains in the world and usually Hilton is a management company. I have noticed through out the years that managed properties take a bit longer to get proper equipment and repairs due to budget restraints.

review_title: Hospitable, Smart, Team-Oriented Legal Group is Outstanding
pros: Hilton's Legal team is full of passionate, engaged staff who work incredibly well together as an integrated team. There are not big egos and the team is the antithesis of the Big Law environment. Overseeing legal operations for hotels around the world ensures there are interesting, varied matters that come across our desk everyday.
cons: The only con is that the team as a whole is very busy, so it is sometimes difficult to take as much care and attention as you would like to certain questions.

review_title: Pay and benefits for those in management are not competitive.
pros:
- Nice managers/employees
- Hotel discounts
- Good work life balance
cons:
- Terrible salaries, even for those in management.
- Expensive healthcare and benefits for those not in unions
- No holiday pay, have to work on holidays unless you use your personal PTO for it. Same for sick days. Only 21 days a year for first 4 or 5 years there. Considering there are at least 8-10 federal holidays that most office employees in any company gets, you only have about 11 days left for any vacation or sick days every year.
- Very stiff, dull culture without any effort by the company to increase employee satisfaction, don't expect any employee perks or bonding here!
- Didn't provide a suitable office for their office workers, instead we were pushed into every unsellable, dark corner of the hotel.

pros:
- I love the Team Member Travel Program! I have gotten to travel to so many fantastic hotels for a very minimal cost.
- Certain positions have the flexibility to work remotely or partially remotely - this has been a phenomenal benefit to me. My work/life balance is the best it has ever been, and I've been in the workforce for 20 years. 
- The culture is very upbeat and positive - everyone prides themselves on delivering fantastic guest service.
cons: - Working anywhere in hospitality, you're going to work weekends, nights, holidays, etc. But even working on a holiday, there's a happy and positive vibe, and your fellow Team Members make it a fun work day.

pros: One of the bright spots for working with Hilton is the training and transparency about the computer systems, sales, and how Hilton functions day to day. OnQ University is a great place to take online courses and pick up skills that might not be a part of your normal job function.
cons: Locally, Hilton has not really taken an interest in how the franchise is run. If they took a really good look, their hotel would be in better shape and our team would be happier. We cut so many corners, our hotel should be built in a circle.

review_title: Ok but no job security or good salary
pros: Overall good benefits, relatively understanding management, if you work very hard for couple of years there will be a promotion/career progression
cons: Low salaries,  employees stretched and overworked in some departments, not enough headcounts to hire more people, very corporate company, if you are creative and looking to for fun and vibrant place to work where people are open minded,  Hilton HQ in Watford is not for you. You will feel very frustrated there. If you are just looking for a job locally with some benefits, it might be good enough...some teams are very cliquey so they might not be the most welcoming from day 1.

review_title: Absolutely Awesome to be at the Heart of Hilton
job_title: Director of Human Resources in Pune
pros: Hilton Worldwide is one of the fastest growing hotel companies in the country and if you are looking at making it big in your hospitality career, this is the place to be. With the number of new hotels coming up, there are ample opportunities for internal transfers, career progressions and international exposures. World-class training opportunities, and a culture of excellence, continuous improvement, and innovation helps you reach your full potential. Best in the industry compensation and benefits are key factors in keeping Hilton employees motivated and loyal to the company. 5 Day Working Week is a key differentiator in the industry and Hilton has been among the first couple of companies to launch this practice.
cons: Emphasis is always on hiring people with the right attitude who can perform to match Hilton's world-class standards of hospitality.

review_title: Being part of the Hilton FAMILY :)
pros:
-	great team spirit! Feels like a big family
-	excellent travel program with very low team member rates
-	first name policy & low hierarchies
-	many team member events (e.g. Kick-Off Team Member Party, sport events etc.)
-	nice team member restaurant
-	great offers regarding health (eyesight tests, stress management training etc. in the hotel)
-	diversity of employees 
-	many ways of recognition
cons: If you would like to boost your career you need to be very flexible regarding the work locations, transferring to hotels in the US, Canada and UK from Europe is not always as easy as many team members wish and if you would like to stay in your country there might not be a suitable position.

pros: Decent benefits package and phenomenal training, especially for those on the career path in the hospitality industry.
cons: Some corporate policies are self-defeating and harm the income potential of certain hotels in the long run.

review_title: The treatment of there staff is very good, along with the great range of employee benefits
pros: i love there benefits they give to there staff and direcly for me, my head of department is great at his job, and treats all his staff with respect.
cons: due to the way the business is going at the moment in terms of finance, there is little chance of promotions at the moment, i also feel although there are loads of benefits there is not as much recognition for the staff in terms of praise

pros:
-Working from home is the BEST.
-Trainers have been VERY helpful so far; however, with so much information to deal with, you'd have to be a very patient trainer. 
- Great team attitude.
-Best virtual on-boarding experience I've had. 
-Travel stay benefits are great.
cons:
-Metrics: there is literally SO much information that is tallied that it is overwhelming.
-Salary: We understand that it's part-time work, but an increase would be beneficial for all.
-Information: While on-boarding is great, it's massive. There is much to be done once you start  and log in (and that's only allowed 5-10 minutes before your shift) that things get lost. You have to be logged into your system, the phone system, the help documents, your email, the help chat and read/comprehend any new information that's posted. It's easy to miss stuff.

pros: I have been working with Hilton for past 6years. The job environment is very educative, friendly, cooperative and exploring. I have been appreciated various times for showing up excellent performance. Initially I started as accounts clerk with Hilton, my passion to create network works and explore the world had made me to switch to purchase department. Thus I can state that Hilton is a place where you can explore your talent, passion and grow up our career.
cons: Every hotel or company will have negatives. The number of negative points will go up & down accordingly to persons. My view is that those who make positives out of the negatives are explorers. Hilton is bond with many rules, regulations and policies. Managing to work with this is difficult but not possible.

job_title: Senior Director in Mc Lean, VA
pros: Great hotels - great people in the hotels.  Nice offices.  Some change for movement
cons: As a 30+ year employee of Hilton - I have seen many changes.  The most significant have been in the last 5 years.  Corporate office morale is horrible.  Hilton has the spin machine working to make it seem like everyone likes their job - but upper management is in a bubble.  HR is a real bubble.  Many in the corporate office have never worked in a hotel and don't know how to communicate with guests.  The guest is no longer a priority with Hilton.  Just profits.  Do more with less mentality.

pros: You will learn great customer service and problem solving skills. It's a great job to work at while in school because you can do homework at work during slow times. The job is easy to learn if you have computer skills. It looks really good on a resume because it does require a lot of different skills.
cons: It can get boring, since you're usually stuck at the front desk, especially on slow days when working alone. It's also exhausting standing for almost 8 hours straight, it can be hard on your feet and joints. Sometimes you'll get yelled at by angry unsatisfied guests for dumb reasons.

review_title: Good benefits for this industry, long hours
pros: Hilton name looks great on the CV, good benefits e.g. staff canteen, discount on booking rooms and restaurants (subject to availability), some very great and motivated team members, good support from HR if one wants to change location after a while
cons: imbalance between what is expected and resources provided (e.g. understaffed), staff is often expected to make up for under staffing by staying longer hours, sometimes without compensation, some promotions clearly not deserved but if staff is senior no action is being taken, lots of unnecessary and impossible to fulfill red tape (e.g. training records), compensation is good for the industry but bad compared to others

pros:
Great work environment, excellent benefits and  options for career progression & travel. Hilton offers its staff heavy discounts in house and on hotel stays overseas. 

They have an extensive career development program and the ability to relocate virtually anywhere in the world.
cons:
Wages are average at best, working hours can be long and at busy times you are often expected to work without a break.

Management are hit and miss, but overall the customer with always come first and the staff members happiness is an afterthought in deed, if not in word.

review_title: Hired at entry level, promoted to Food and Beverage Director, with company for 5 years.
job_title: Food and Beverage Director in Edinburgh, IN
pros: Easy to climb the ladder in a few short years with little expierience. Big brand name for your resume. Over 500 locations worldwide you could apply at.
cons: High turnover makes it difficult to build a team at any level, even managment. Little control over products standards and menus in the restaurant.

review_title: Not good for anyone who doesn't fit neatly into Hilton's limited definition of a good employee.
job_title: Customer Care Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Good travel benefits, ability to work at home.
cons: Limited ability to get time off.  Difficult to change schedules. Makes you feel like you've lost control of your own life.  Employees who think outside the box--even when it is to the advantage of the company--are discouraged.  Tools for further empowerment are repeatedly promised, but they are the proverbial pot at the end of the rainbow.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: They truly care about employees before guests. Not to say that their guests aren't treated like VIPs, they just care that much about the people who work there. Everyone knows each other and encourages each other. It's incredibly easy to do amazing work when it feels like you're working with friends who want to see the hotel succeed as much as you do. It's almost like a cult -- you will not meet anyone there who tells you they don't treasure their job, and if they do have issues, management is incredibly supportive. Best place to work in the Columbus area.
cons: November through February is incredibly slow. It's the nature of the business though, not necessarily this hotel's fault. Sometimes turnover is high in more entry-level positions

review_title: Overall a good company and definitely some great benefits
pros: One of the perks I love the most with working for Hilton is the team member travel program, great discounted rates with the caveat that you pick hotels that are not in major cities and it's generally off peak (off season, mid week).  The culture is very accepting and friendly.
cons: The biggest downside with working with corporate is location, Mclean is quite a commute from dc and even with the metro stop at Tyson, its about an hour from any place on the dc side.  They are making some improvements, but individual and leadership development is behind what you would find in other major companies.

pros: Full-time employees get great benefits. A lot of the other departments get recognized for their hard work often, ours not so much. Hotel discounts! Full, part, or on-call these are the greatest perks for those that love to travel!
cons:
Hotels don't close.
Our department seems to be undervalued. I do my job well, but no motivation to really go over the top and achieve more.

job_title: Food and Beverage in Portsmouth, England
pros: - Looks good on your CV
cons:
- Lazy and imcompetent managers (up to head of department level).
- HR promotes suck ups who have ticked boxes rather than experienced and capable staff.
- Long shifts, poor work/life balance
- Low pay and tips that dont find their way to your payslip.
- Management do not care about their staff, only the numbers and are very lazy.
- Management cant seem to write a rota more than one day in advance (is available on Thursday, starts the next day) which makes planning the rest of your life next to impossible.

job_title: Food and Beverage in Portsmouth, England
pros: - Looks good on your CV
cons:

- Management do not care about their staff, only the numbers and are very lazy.
- Management cant seem to write a rota more than one day in advance (is available on Thursday, starts the next day) which makes planning the rest of your life next to impossible.

review_title: Hilton Worldwide/HRCC work-at-home reservations sales specialist
job_title: HRCC Reservation Sales Specialist in Carrollton, TX
pros:
Positive, respectful work environment.
Well-planned, effective training program.
Flexible scheduling that lets me pick my days off.
Good discounts and free hotels after training.
No commute allows me to keep more of the paycheck.
cons:
Low hourly rate.
Tough to make all the metrics for potential bonuses, and Hilton network issues negatively impact these metrics.
At times system and network connection issues make it tough to do the job, and they are fairly regular occurrences.
These are the only truly negative issues of consequence I have experienced, so far.

review_title: Hilton Worldwide in Addison Tx is a an office that has great Benefits, Salary, and Culture.
pros: One of the greatest aspects for working at Hilton Worldwide in Addison is the Office Environment and the unlimited resources that are within reach. Titles are not important and everyone chips in to make the success of the company a better performer. Training Content is wonderful. Benefits and Salary are some of the most competitive in the industry.
cons: Due to the rapid growth and recently becoming a publicly traded company there have been some increasing red-tape.

review_title: Great benefits, everything else is OK
job_title: Guest Service Agent in Honolulu, HI
pros: The benefits are out of this world. The travel program gets you rooms for free or for around $60 based on availability). Depending on your location and status you get great compensation like competitive wages, health, dental, and retirement plans.
cons: In my experience it has been hard to advance your career unless you transfer to a different hotel. You could also get the impression that money is the priority and not the guest. That was pretty frustrating for me because I really care about people. I've also seen a lot of back and forth on operating procedures, today we do one thing but tomorrow the rule changed and on the weekend we are back to the original way

pros: Overall,  the apprenticeship scheme had its good and worst. What I liked the most was going into college.  You had a lot of support from the tutor. I would also say that the paid holidays were good and free meals provided on duty.
cons: Even though college was college, the work place was terrible.  They promised to move you to another hotel to working after 6 months but they changed their minds. Also not to forget that the managers and even other colleagues with the same title treat so disrespectfully. They made my life miserable.

review_title: Proud to be apart of Hilton
pros: Working with Hilton brings the family feel from home to work. I feel empowered  by my colleagues and management to share the idea's I have  whilst being supported in the decision's I make. The training and development Hilton offer's you exceeds your expectations, whilst if you show passion, commitment and enthusiasm for what you do, in return Hilton invests and recognises you as an individual.
cons: The influx of new marketing and promotions can be overwhelming and hard to learn and implement.  Example, Meet with Purpose, Meetings Simplified, Ready to Rise, Travel with Purpose are all great incentives however implementing them within the property is hard as there is not one focus at a time.

review_title: Food and Beverage can pay well.
pros: Restaurant in the Doubletree offered a lot of hours and usually made good tips from guests. Good benefits for working for Hilton, discounts on rooms around the country. Opportunities to cross-train to do other jobs in food and beverage.
cons: I worked at a Hilton Garden Inn where the management was terrible and they took the service charge tips from room service for themselves. They wanted you to set up for banquets while only being payed on server wage. There are a lot of idiots that these hotels will hire that are very difficult to work with and management does not care.

job_title: Customer Care Coordinator in Carrollton, TX
pros: You get discounted and sometimes free rooms at hotels, flexible schedule, lots of pto and sick time, working from home is the best, lots of activities on site, discounts on non hilton items, many different departments to advance in, great job for stay at home parents and people in school, family members also get travel benefits.
cons: Sometimes the systems don't work or kick you out mid-call which can make it hard to do your job and its very frustrating, maintenance on the website is always scheduled at a time that's very inconvenient for everyone, communication between people that work at home and people that work on site is lacking big time. Email is the main mode of communication when you work from home and sometimes it's more likely to win the lottery 10 times than it is to get a response from my boss. Policies change so often that it's hard to keep up and then we have agents telling customers outdated information. Not to mention A LOT of hotel workers aren't trained on the hhonors program so they give false info and 9 times out of 10 we're the ones that get yelled at by customers about it and we're left apologizing and trying to fix someone else's mess.

job_title: Bellman in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: General Manager is fantastic. HR team, training, etc. was top-notch, and I really valued working for the Hilton brand. Wonderful location. Tips were pretty good. Fellow bellmen/concierge/front desk staff were great to work with. Interaction with guests was enjoyable.
cons:
Bellman shoe policy. Changed from anything black and comfortable (i.e., comfortable black New Balance tennis shoes) to strictly dress shoes (i.e., hard bottom sole, uncomfortable, less flexible, harder to move around in) right as I was leaving my job. I don't know if I would have survived working there in dress shoes due to the constant standing, running, loading/unloading of luggage all day. I fear my back and feet would have had more issues.

Parking was on our own, wherever we could find it a few blocks away.

pros: Opportunity to meet, interact and communicate with a wide variety of guests, clients, patrons and personality types.  Was enabled to be somewhat creative  and proactive whilst performing a diverse assortment tasks.
cons: The micromanagement style of the owner prevented employees from developing a sense of responsibility and confidence in their ability to successfully perform their roles at the company, it stifled creativity increased stress and in the long run resulted in a high turn-over rate of employees who were already overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Say Goodbye To Any Semblance of a Normal Life
pros: You get insurance. Sometimes the customers leave cash tips.
cons: Ridiculously poor management in the food/bev departments. Schedules come out on Wednesday’s for the following Friday. Haphazard hours. Almost constantly understaffed. Constant contention and drama.  Many shifts with no breaks. Bathroom breaks are even hard to swing (you have to ask a manager to come cover for you—Nope, not joking). Wages are stagnant. Constant “blackouts” during which you cannot request time off—no exceptions. A general attitude of disrespect toward all service positions from upper management. Not worth the disruption in your daily life.

pros: Healthy Business environment , professional team, helpful management system , everyday new challenges , dine dining tools ، added value in personal level , great experience and exciting events
cons: marketing strategies and sales tools , changes in upper management frequently, Finincial management interference , sales calls and getting appointments , shortage in sales coordinators which put more pressure on sales manager to do extra time for paper work when he or suppose to be on the market and planing day to day appointments ,

pros:
Mostly great people
Travel benefits 
Lots of vacation time
cons:
-The "culture" is outwardly great and fun, but inwardly phony, phony, phony....the longer you stay there, the harder it is to swallow. 
- It was sickening to me how much the company sucks up to the interns and fetes them like celebrities. They are treated far better than the rest of the employees are. Ugh. And they're so young and naive, they just eat it all up and walk around with starry eyes. So just beware if you intern there, that it will not always be like that. It's an act. You'll really miss that VIP treatment once you become a real employee.

review_title: Opportunities Dictated by whether property is Corporate or Franchised Controlled
job_title: Front Desk Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Engaging culture. If you're a people person than opportunities are aplenty to engage, interact and sometimes mean unique individuals from all over the world. My particular property is franchised and so thus pay isn't something you're going to survive off of nor are there any benefits, I'm sure this can vary from property-to-property.
cons: As stated, the pay isn't phenomenal. This is somewhat expected as this is a service sector position but just as well there aren't benefits of any kind, even with regards to full-time employment.

review_title: Great Company Depending On Your Location
job_title: Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Enjoyed my time at Hilton. My last year with the company was challenging with a change management.
cons:
After many years with Hilton, my last year was eye opening to the fact that growth was limited unless you moved to other cities. Since I wasn’t able to do that, I decided to leave after new management destroyed the team I was on.  Hilton Salt Lake City Center has been a sinking ship for many years and people do not enjoy being there.  That is why many people have left. 

Pay is low until you move up and even then raises are slow to be earned. You really had to fight for your raises. 


My specific property was a less than stellar experience so the only negative portion of my review is specific to the property. Hilton as a company is headed in the right direction.

pros:
Benefits mainly (health ins excellent and the discounted hotel stays great)
I was able to make my own schedule within their guidelines
cons:
- Major pressure to always produce more even when I was one of top sales rep.
- Strict and tell you when you have to take your bathroom break even when work from home
- Daily tech problems that hindered you from performing task
- In order to move dept they want you to have experience in other departments that you can't get training in. Not sure how to move around in system with their limitations.
- Low compensation
- The role was not a good fit for someone with years of working experience. I took a entry level role because recruiter said everyone starts there.

pros: A lot of autonomy. Definitely have opportunity to make the best of the opportunity you are given. Typical Corporate world, but have to make your own path if you can. If you like hospitality, this is the type of environment you'd like to be a part of.
cons: Bosses are very much on top of you if they are insecure about themselves and their own performance. You have to be with the in crowd in order to move up. If you are not, you will become stagnant in whatever it is you may be doing.

pros:
Fantastic Team Members that deeply care about their co-workers and our guests, and creating great experiences for all.
Outstanding CEO and leadership team that values our rich history but continues to innovate and drive our company forward into the future.
Amazing travel program that gives us the opportunity to see the world.
Genuine commitment to corporate responsibility and a desire to make a difference in our communities.
Investment in wellness, learning and development, and other key resources that help our Team Members be their best.
Proud history of promoting from within.
cons: As with any big organization, there are lots of people to consult when making big decisions.  That can make "speed to market" tricky, but not impossible.

pros:
Scheduling flexibility, team member travel benefits start day one, health and medical benefits, hands on training.

The base pay for the at home reservation position is on the low end, but for me it works great. I can set my schedule weekly around school, appointments, and I'm guaranteed 40 hours. The weekend requirement is manageable and the health benefits are spectacular. If you can meet the minimum sales goals and pocket a few extra hundred dollars each month it covers your insurance (family, individual health was less than $60 for the full smorgasbord). I can't wait to continue growing with Hilton. They do at home work right.
cons: None so far, this is a sales position so there is emphasis on upselling so if sales is not comfortable for you this can be seen as a con.

job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good company benefits that included a competitive 401K match and an employee purchase program of Hotel products, such as bedding. I worked for a couple of Hilton properties that included downtown urban Hotels as well as a resort. It was fun to sell the brand, but the product always seemed to be dated compared to the competition.
cons: Competitive goals, stressful work environment, tons of reporting deadlines and too many negative team members ready to sabotage your efforts.

review_title: They don’t care about anyone but themselves
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: The clients who come there.... if they don’t end up leaving from the dirty rooms or unprofessional management company. The location is nice.
cons: They don’t care about their employees, their bonus structure is one of the worst in hotel industry. They make it up as they go, there is no team moral, communication is non existent there. You don’t know who’s direction to take as there are too many hands in the pot. The management company knows nothing about running a hotel. They do things under the table until they get caught. They’ve had more people sue them then I could count.. not to mention non staff. All I am going to say is they pay you and expect you to work like a slave.

job_title: Restaurant Server in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The only Pros I experienced working here is the same benefits every employee gets. Great benefits. Travel Program and steady hours.
cons: Seniority rules.You could be the best employee and management couldn't care less. You could be the worst employee and as long as you're close to management, you'd get the best treatment. Supplies are limited. Management is cheap. No structure. Anything goes. Probably the worst management team and crew that I've ever encountered. Too many turn overs, Nobody wants to stay at this location.

pros: Good benefits from health, eye, dental and 401k.  Steady hours.  Friendly atmosphere among employees which helps create a positive atmosphere.
cons: Very demanding which is fine although too many political games with management.  Line employees are often taken advantage off and management forgets often the hard work the staff contributes.  Employees never are appreciated or recognized to say the least.  Human resources are way behind the times when it comes to employee relations which shows in Salt scores.

pros: The advantage of working in the Hotel Industry is the opportunity to interact and meet people from all over the world.  If you are not planning to stay in that industry and are working there only for a short period of time, you could network and establish relationships that may lead you to different opportunities.
cons: You really meet people of all kind.  It is easy to jump in nice customers, but also very easy to find disrespectful and arrogant people.  So, it is important to remember to be professional under all circumstances.

review_title: F & B supervisor/banquet manager/F & B manager
job_title: F & B Supervisor, Banquet Manager in Falls Church, VA
pros: with my experience/knowledge ,i was able to change and improved the service,quality and food presentation to our guest of the hotel from the restaurant and banquets,increasing sales and revenue for the hotel ,created ways to be able to save  from the previous management contracts with vendor ,increased the quality of products that we offer to our hotel guests ,from the market store,our bar,dinning room,banquets, making this hotel the very best we can offer to our community
cons: unfortunately when you deal with a management and owners that dont appreciated and squeeze as much they can ,the corporation should look very closed with franchise hotels that varly give the benefits to the employees

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Corvallis, OR
pros: Everyone feels like family. The management team does its best to fit everybody's schedules and keep them happy. There is a lot of constructive criticism so one is able to grow and become a better employee.
cons: Very low chance for growth within company, at least this location. There are departments that treat other departments like they dont exist. As a front desk team member get ready to have the sales department walk all over you and make messes for you to clean up.

pros: pay and benefits unmatched anywhere on the entire island. some of the best benefits for medical dental vision (401k for non union employees has a great match program)...Union gets free benefits, but union dues especially their "cut" on your overtime pay can be annoying...
cons: its work after all in hawaii where everyday is a beautiful day. The property is massive so if dont have a job that requires you to walk or visit end to end and all thats in the middle you may not really know what is going on at the hotel.

pros:
Work From Home is good
The Discounts are good
Flexible schedule (if offered) you can work the schedule you want.
cons:
If you can not get the flex schedule and have a set schedule, they can change your schedule and do not care if you do not like the new schedule.
The pay is not good. Some departments are good, some departments are not good. They have favoritism in some departments and if you are a kiss up or their friend, you can get promoted before a person that has more experience

pros: Hilton is great about letting everyone know they are valued and have a part in Hilton's success. When I began working here several years ago I started as an administrative assistant. Now, 4 job titles later, I help to manage a global project and work with individuals in several different countries. That wouldn't have happened had I not been encouraged to expand my horizons and grow my skills. Maybe it's just the hospitality field but the camaraderie at Hilton spans any boundary, language, religion, job title, ethnicity or time zone. We're all a family and we're all working here together to make a positive impact. I enjoy it so much I'm trying to get my family and friends hired on at Hilton as well.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

job_title: Senior Revenue Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: I could go on and on about the Pros of Hilton but the ones that stick out to me include the work-life balance, the company culture, the passion to develop team members and the encouragement we have to challenge ourselves to learn something new each day. Hilton has gave me more opportunities to grow both personally and professionally throughout the last 5 years and with the opportunities that this company has and vision for the future, I have no plans to relocate elsewhere.
cons: It could been seen as a con for the compensation in roles within Hilton. However, the pros of work-life balance, PTO, and culture out-weigh this for most.

job_title: Not A Current Employee in Prague
pros: By staying ahead of the curve in pay scale overall they are able to attract some of the more talented chef's in the city. Unfortunately this is minor with the infighting that goes on.
cons: If you enjoy the idea of working in a very internally politicized job, then this would be the place for you. Infighting over the few available promotions changed a possibly great job into a drudge. Add in the separate pay scales for local and foreign workers, a remnant of a bygone era when foriegn talent wouldn't come to a communist country and you have a recipe for dissatisfaction.

pros:
I work at the RMCC and love that we still have the camaraderie and community you usually only find on property, but we have a more regular schedule that allows me to actively participate in my kids' lives. Regular does not mean there is no room for flexibility and we also get a work from home day each week. 
Hilton is always moving forward and values innovation and input from the team. Training is always available and updated constantly.
cons: With a great benefits packet unfortunately comes cost for the company, so the salaries are not as high as they would be working elsewhere, but that really is only a con if money is more important than having those benefits like work from home, insurance, team member travel, schedule flexibility.

job_title: Group Rooms Coordinator in Clearwater, FL
pros: Lots of job openings due to lack of caring from management!!
cons: Hilton caters to guests with no care for employees whatsoever.  They make senior management so scared to get a bad review, they allow guests and encourage from what I can see, to demand whatever they want and know they will get it depending on their level.  Diamond members are out of control and make day to day work absolutely miserable.

review_title: If you can handle the pace
pros: Great hospitaility organization - believes in employee's - takes a great deal of time to get anything accomplished - very decentralized - fast paced and growing organization - lots of hotels and plans on the horizon - upcoming move from California may be challanging -
cons: Very de-centralized organization with a split personality. Has had a great deal of executive level turnover in the past few months - needs to integrate as a whole and also have sound business practices in place - needs to shrink it's senior and upper management and make them less hotel operations and more corporate centric - empower the employee to make decisions and move forward with business plans.

review_title: Front Desk Clerk / Engineering Department / Payroll (current)
pros:
•Meeting new people. This is a perfect chance to practice your soft skills and learn to effectively communicate across cultures. 

•The enormous satisfaction you get from making other people feel welcome and happy. 

•An opportunity to start a career without any experience or education. That doesn’t mean you should have some basic understanding of the industry or possess the necessary features like an open mind and being an easy-going kind of person.
cons:
•Working weekends and holidays. Yes, almost all of them. Including Christmas, your friends’ birthdays, weddings, and if you’re unlucky, your own b-day too. 

•Stressful environment. That makes part of any job related to working with people. That’s because we’re not machines, and anything can go wrong when the human factor is involved.

pros: Nice guest that are fun and interesting to meet. Some staff friendly and helpful.
cons: In order for wait staff to make ok money, they only schedule 2 at a time and they rotate serving guests with running room service. Makes for a crazy hectic work environment and not to great service to guests. Some staff were rude or condescending about getting with the program. Uncomfortable uniforms and long shifts with more cleaning duties (like moping floors) than any other place I've worked.

pros: The primary reason to work for Hilton and it's subsidiaries (I worked at a Hampton Inn) is for the discounts, both for you and your family.  The freedom is also nice.
cons: In the 'entry-level' positions you won't get much in the way of compensation.  I think I made less than people working at McDonald's. The hours are rough, and if someone on the shift after you calls in, you'll often be expected to work their shift.  I once worked for 20 hours straight as a result of this.

review_title: Good pay and secure. But they will work you to the bone.
job_title: Director of Marketing in Dallas, TX
pros: Great co-workers. Good pay. Great benefits. While the morale in the Dallas offices is not the greatest due to the fact that no one has been promoted in that office without moving to the Virginia HQ, most of the people at Hilton are genuinely nice people who are always willing and able to pitch in to help. While there are cons (as there are with any job), I would still recommend Hilton as a great place to work.
cons: No opportunity for advancement unless you move to the HQ in Virginia. They will work you to the bone. And there is WAY too much red tape for anyone to be effective in their role. The offices are a little bleak, but nice.

review_title: Terrible Management, by the book and illogical
pros: Flexible scheduling. It was possible to work at different positions within the company, but obviously they would limit you to under 40 hours a week to avoid paying overtime. HR was very nice and respectable, but acted only as therapists and never really did anything worthwhile.
cons: Management had no idea what was going on; from the GM to assistant managers, they were running around like chickens with their heads cut off daily. They couldn't handle the smallest issues that arose, especially at big events. When corporate came to visit once a month or so, they made no changes and gave no advice. In fact, I didn't see corporate do a single thing other than walk around the property and nod their heads.

review_title: The most secured place to work
pros: From my point of view; I have been working in the human resources field since 8 years and I have witnessed a lot of benefits starts with the working environment in general and the good relation between the team and the management, the communication style that allows everyone to exactly the widely important goal and his role to achieve, the feeling of success and the joy to celebrate and share happiness. Also, developing in people and the support the one has to go further in his personal development,
cons: as a general package is moderate however in terms of salary scale that needs to be reviewed versus the competitors sets that extract the calipers.

pros: In my opinion Hilton in one of the best companies in the Hospitality Industry.  It is really guest and TMs oriented. I truly believe in our Mission, Vision and Values, that is why I am extremely happy to be part of the Team. What I like most are the opportunities that the company gives you for advancement and also that it is very innovative.
cons: What i do not like is that most of the time it is really hard to have the Work/Life Balance. There are to many resposibilities that needs to be done by 1 person for 1 working day and  this leads to work overtime, tired and unhappyTeam Members. And when the salary is lower compared to other properties in the city, Team members are losing their motivation.

review_title: Constant system issues which affected pay, and made for VERY unhappy guests that we in turn had to deal with.
job_title: Reservation Sales Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Working from home. Fair wages. Period.
cons: You are micro managed to the 'nth' degree.  Every single call is monitored.  If you sneeze, they know about it.  No matter how long you are there, the monitoring never ceases.  Lack of trust from the company gets very old.  Not much room for advancement.  System issues would be fixed, only to have the same issues come up again and again.  Wasn't happy with some of it's business practices.  Lastly, tons of misdirected calls that affected your stats, and therefore your wages.

review_title: Room Attendant at Hilton Birmingham Metropole
pros:
Really easy interview, easy to get even with a low level of English.
Career Pogression: a promotion to manager was offerered after 9 months
Good working environment: colleagues are really supportive and kind.
Multicultural environment: it is easy to make friends.
Free meals
Goog working hours: 9 am to 3 pm
Bonus. You can earn up to £1,200 p/m for a 6 h daily working, after 9 months
cons:
Realy fast paced environment: (cleaning 13 check out rooms, 26 stay-in rooms or a combination of both + moving between floors + replenish trolley) in 6 h due to lack of employees.
High level of rotation: people usually change to other departments as soon as they can.
High levels of cleanliness required by some managers sometimes can be difficult to get in the time given.
Weekends working required

pros:
Ability to work remotely
True work-life balance
Management mentors and are actively involved in their team's success
Opportunities to learn other fields
Job opportunities always available
Excellent benefits - travel program and discount programs
cons:
Large companies are sometimes hard to work for at first and some new employees get lost in the shuffle. Employees must be outspoken about their goals and their desire for opportunities.

review_title: 10 years strong, and hope to continue thriving at Hilton for years to come!

So you become very sedentary and you can start to feel isolated since you are not in a  office environment.
