If you enjoy gossip and unprofessional management that bully front line employees.  You will love it here.
cons: Executive Committee are disorganized.  Communications between all departments are fractured with no hope of being repaired.  Management handles interdepartmental interaction much like in high school.  Management is very cliquish and don't expect to get any time off the schedule if your manager dislikes you.  Favoritism is rampant here.

pros: Lots of PTO with management support to use it; flexible work environment (work from home one day per week and during winter holidays); management is approachable and usually willing to go the distance to solve problems; discounts on hotel stays and a wide variety of non-hotel related discounts (cell phone, mattresses, etc); overall positive office culture with numerous volunteer opportunities and fun events held throughout the year; decent training and development programs; perfect place for a new college graduate or those with a family and desire job stability
cons: High level management seems to lack the ability to plan more than a few months in advance (numerous team members have desks in meeting rooms due to lack of space); last-minute initiatives with dubious goals and lack of transparency regarding their impact on the business; lack of transparency in regards to promotions; lack of opportunities to move up the ladder within the RMCC (you will either manage hotels or manage people here) or within Hilton (the Dallas office seems very removed from the rest of the company); increase in nepotism within the past two years (a curiously high number of lower and middle managers have out-of-office connections with leadership i.e. babysitters, gym buddies, friends of family, etc.); lack of incentives to improve personal performance (typical 3% yearly pay increase; no bonuses for non-management positions; salary caps for promotions)

pros: The company improved the travel benefit for team members, education assistance benefit, a large amount of resources for career development, excellent paid time off program, genuine line level staff and ability to work from home one day a week.

cons: As with any growing company there are always hiccups along the way. It's the same with life and nothing is perfect, it's all about how you perceive it.

review_title: Great Perks, Poor Ecommerce Department Leadership
pros: Competitive pay rate, great paid vacation accrual (4 weeks of PTO in first year), excellent hotel discounts and other perks. Work-life balance is exceptional. One work from home day a week is a great perk. Addison, TX office is well located, and there are some great people who work in eCommerce. The work is not too stressful if you can manage relationships with hotels effectively.
cons:
Ecommerce managers have limited levers to that can be used to drive revenue. Franchise hotels don't have to follow recommendations from ecommerce on setting aside budget for digital marketing, so we are forced to rely on cheap/free tactics that can't drive much revenue. Despite not being given the proper tools to drive results, we are expected to deliver them nonetheless. 

Ecommerce leadership is weak, disconnected and opaque, all the way up to CLR (one of our VPs). I don't believe they try to be secretive, I just don't think they possess the skills and expertise to effectively set annual strategies, milestones and communicate their vision properly. As a result, the department feels directionless, has been passed around to numerous senior executives, and is now being gutted to bolster the ranks of the current executive's pet discipline - destination marketing.

Favoritism runs rampant and substandard employees have been fast tracked into middle management roles because they latched onto the right coattails, despite having glaring skill set and knowledge gaps (one of them promoted to director of social media after less than a year as a senior manager without knowing how Facebook ads work - seriously). Office politics exist everywhere, but Hilton is the worst example of it I have seen in my long career. Your performance doesn't matter as long as your managers like you as a person.

The good news is myself and a few lucky others survived the PNG purge and will continue to make good money with a good work-life balance after the dust settles. I feel bad for those who are having to take a demotion or look outside the company to achieve one executive's power play. The bad news is the ones who prevent the department from excelling are still running it. I give it a few more years before they just fold eCommerce into a more competently run part of the organization, like Advice or Revenue Management.

If we had the same strong leadership present in those departments, we might be growing in size and company influence. Too bad we don't.

Also, things are very silo'd within this organization--you will waste significant time just trying to get in touch with the right people who can impart change. pros: If you're a build-a-schedule agent you get to make your own hours (within company rules, such as a minimum number of hours per week, a minimum number of hours in your scheduled block, and a minimum number of weekend hours).  You can manage which days you need off in the event there is something you want to attend. There's no commute, which is great. You're home so you can work in your PJs if you choose. You are close to your family and you never have to travel in bad weather. The pay isn't terrible for a work-at-home position.
cons: The metrics of this company are almost impossible to meet. You are asked to conform to a very high standard such as the amount of people you book or the amount of time you spend on the phone with each person. You are (like others have said) micro-managed to death. You are given one 15 minute break for every 3 hours you work (and a lunch if you go over 6 hours) but don't expect to get any other time away from the computer outside of those scheduled breaks. If you have to use the bathroom and you just took your 15-minute break you're screwed. You can't clock out without facing repercussions such as being written up for attendance or your availability. Once you are written up three times you're terminated. Doesn't matter WHAT you were written up for, as long as you were written up three times you're gone. You could be given a new boss with absolutely no warning. Also the discrepancy between bosses is ridiculous. What was okay with one, may not be okay with another. What was said to be "company-policy" by one may not even be company policy. Also, it's an extremely busy job. Don't work here if you're looking for something to do while you take care of other people like kids or grandparents. You will be on the phone from the time you sign in until you sign out again. Calls during the busy seasons (from about march to October) were back to back. You will hang up with one person and the next call automatically drops in. It gets overwhelming, it gets stressful, and it gets to be exhausting. You will have no choice but to answer the calls and keep doing what they're paying you to do and hope that your "metrics" survive until the end of your shift or you're going to be written up for not performing well.

job_title: Front Office Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Hilton likes to promote from within, so there's plenty of promotion opportunities whether it's within the department or somewhere else. Hilton hotels are all over the place, so there's the potential to relocate and they make it very easy
Travel benefits are a nice perk. Hilton is also rolling out new maternity/paternity benefits for families and adoption assistance.
It's hospitality so you're always meeting new people.
cons:
It's a customer service job so it can test your patience.
Time off can be hard to come by and the hours can be rough.

review_title: Recently bought by private equity and being run into the ground
pros: There is always something happening, and interesting technology challenges that revolve around the unique business model. Pay is high if you are not in the LA or European offices.
cons:
Bought by private equity and being run into the ground. Hilton is not a good bet right now from a career perspective. Wait until the layoffs, outsourcing and restructuring are complete sometime in 2009.

The company lacks solid management and is not process driven. This can be frustrating if you come from a more structured organization with documented, repeatable business processes. 

The organization is not standardized or structured for efficiency.

pros: Great family atmosphere within my department, though this is most likely because we spent so much time together.  Work was always changing with new clients on a daily basis.
cons: Salaried F&B managers were expected to work 70-80 hours a week with no overtime.  No provisions for retirement savings and/or planning + company contribution to health/dental/vision insurance was meager.

review_title: Not the same company since Blackstone acquired it.  All pride and loyalty in the parent company is gone.
pros: Good brands that have strong leadership.
cons: Current corporate management is focused solely on desperately trying to wring profit out of what was acquired by Blackstone. People who have given their entire careers to HHC are now afraid for their futures. More would leave, but with the economy the way it is, many have nowhere to go.

review_title: Good company, just a bad location
pros: The benefits are good (401k, insurance, PTO, employee rate rooms), with a company this large there is (needed) structure, room for internal growth and movement all over the world
cons: Upper management at the property doesn't enforce that all employees do their job, I have worked crazy hours picking other people's slack. Several employees just waiting to retire when they are already burned out. For the amount of business, this hotel does not have enough employees. Everyone wears several hats, expect to do above and beyond your original job description.

review_title: Lots of commendation, easy to be categorized on potential based on one persons opinion
pros: Great opportunity, recruit from inside, give lots of learning opportunities too.
cons:
Pay is not something you will ever be happy with, performance reviews you are placed into one of nine boxes based on performance and potential, easy to be placed in low which is totally un-motivating.
39 hour working week which you will never ever do - salaried employees are not able to claim overtime or time off in lieu.

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Washington, DC
pros: So glad the Hilton recruiter found me! I wasn't looking to leave my job but after speaking with Bryan I felt just maybe the passion I felt he had for Hilton I could have also. My interview was perfect! I felt welcomed every one smiled and spoke to each other. First time I have had an interview with lunch!  Have not been on the job very long but I love it and am glad I made the jump!
cons: Somtimes you don't know when you are working until a couple days before.

pros:
It is a large company with many opportunities worldwide.
There are opportunities to grow within the company, either internally in one property or within other properties. Regionally or Inter Continental.
Large diversity of working environment properties, from the varied brands with Hilton, giving an opportunity to many cultures to work at.
cons:
Being such a large company worldwide, there are challenges in hiring always talented Team Members.
Many different cultures of Team members, there are times that is difficult to keep everyone satisfied

review_title: I have worked for many years in guest services with Hilton and have enjoyed it.
pros: The current G.M. really cares about the guests and employees, which helps employee moral  and due to the Hotel Union, the pay and employee benefits are exceptional.
cons: Too many lower management people that do not have the proper managing skills.

pros: RMCC management really does a job of creating a great work environment for growth and learning as well as a good work life balance. There are plenty of happy hours as well as community volunteer opportunities to keep help build team unity outside of the office.  You also get a discount in the cafeteria as a Hilton employee, and don't forget special room rates at Hilton hotels around the world!
cons: With all the perks that are provided your base salary is not going to be as high as other places potentially. There is also a lot of room for promotions but the pay scale stays on the low end.

review_title: Great Company Depending on the Location
job_title: Night Audit Supervisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Excellent travel benefits and 401k match
cons: Scheduling is never consistent unless in a management role and while pay is listed as competitive, it is often barely above minimum wage and far below what competing companies in the area are paying.

pros: If you are luck enough to work for a corporate property you'll get decent insurance, and PTO.  PTO is great!!  Much better progra that 2 week vacation a year.  I've worked for Hilton for 5 years and earn 9 hours of PTO every two weeks!  Also, if you work for a corporate hilton, you are able to stay at other corporate hilton properties for free!!  I spent 7 nights in CABO on my honeymoon for nothing!  You also receive discounts at other hilton properties.  Stay away from franchises.
cons: very few corporate properties in my area.  Most are franchised.

pros:
Great benefits
Good training
Opportunities to work anywhere
cons: The division I was in managed the hotels and either didn't have a clue as to what service and hospitality is or just didn't care. It was all numbers and seeing how much they could cut...and cut...and cut. It's sad because I saw a lot of very good and very dedicated people come and go because they couldn't provide the service and warmth to the guests because of understaffing/overworking/no corporate support.

pros: Meeting people from all walks of life, and truly enjoying the experience.
cons: This company focuses on negatives rather than the good. Reprimands on everything...They don;t like to praise good work. I believe they think it is a motivator but they are sadly mistaken. Middle and upper management has sticky floor syndrome. Talk of empowerment but when you make a legitimate decision that is great for the business and cost effective, all of management jumps down your throat. My coworkers were always afraid to make decisions on there own because of this. It was annoying.

review_title: At home Reservation Specialist dallas tx.
job_title: Work At Home Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: This was for a at home reservation "specialist", in Dallas TX, there were really no pros, aside from the minuscule discount they give you, if you every have the chance to travel, which you have to go through red tape.
cons: The "I" in Hilton stands for integrity... But its funny because they literally want you to pay for a land line, equipment to do the work, with 7 weeks of mandatory training on 9 bucks an hour. IF they did have any integrity whatsoever they would know no one can live off of that and pay for your own equipment, and yet be forced to train for doing basic tasks.

review_title: HRCC is a good company to work for
pros: With BAS (build a schedule) it is very flexible, The people who work for HRCC are awesome!
cons: I wish we got paid more and that they cared more about us taking care of the customers (which will in-turn come back to Hilton hotels to make us all more money in the long run.. However, they are pushing more and more about up-selling, cross selling, spend more, spend more, spend more!.. I understand we need to get them to spend however, if we push people to much they are going to run from Hilton then where are we going to be!

pros: Work/life balance. Great leaders,  loyalty among workers and great benefits. Professional work envirnoment, you work for your money but you get a lot of perks and help.
cons: Lover of meetings...you meet to meet about meetings and then re-meet to discuss the meeting about meetings. It's a more structured corporate environment, so the ladder to rise can seem steep however if you work hard, you are recognized for your efforts. It's a demanding workforce with competent people...the weak do not advance or do not survive.

review_title: Joined Hilton 6 months ago and couldn't be happier
pros: Incredibly positive work environment. Maybe it is because the Hospitality Industry tends to attract positive, motivated and down to Earth professionals, but it is the best company I ever worked for.
cons: No real con other than because it is such an international company and we deal with colleagues all around the globe, sometimes I have to have calls at night or early morning, but that is it. When you like your job like I do, this is not really a con, just part of the deal.

job_title: Corporate Sales Manager in Waco, TX
pros: Great opportunity for advancement or cross training due to the large number of positions and hotels located across the world.  If you are an outstanding employee, it will be easy to advance.  Also, being able to travel and receive free room nights from a Hilton brand is an added benefit.
cons: Compensation and pay is low which is a norm in hospitality.  Also, sometimes expect long hours if you work any of the catering departments or food service.  The Catering Sales Manager work a lot of hours and their sales quota is pretty high because the hotel can generate a lot of revenue.

review_title: Great Company!!! Let Blackstone finish "global restructuring" before joining
pros: they care about the people working for them.  opportunites all over the country.  Very Diverse.  Lots of experienced people running the company.  Internal Controls are very tight.  Payroll and Wages are administered in a very fair and equitable manner.  you will not ever make more as an hourly person than anyone in that position who has been their the same amount of time as you.  As long as HR has something to say about it.
cons: The owners of the hotels we run wont put enough money into the properties.

job_title: Director of Sales in Des Moines, IA
pros: 1. Interactions with "guests/group leaders".  It's nice to meet everyone from different parts of the country and world.  Though same faces are nice, different ones are, as well.

pros: Good People. Austin vibe. The quest to make the brand stand out in one for the craziest towns in America Aways looking for the next big thing. The Best Bell-stand in Austin. Great GM.  Laid back with 4 diamond guarantee.

pros:

review_title: Great company. Good benefits. Still growing!

job_title: Senior Social Media Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: I've been with Hilton for 5 years, and hope to have many years ahead of me with this great company. cons: I have no cons to share at this time.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Coronado, CA
pros:
Hilton really cares about their team members and makes sure they feel valued and have opportunities to grow. They have a lot of opportunities for training. The team member travel program is an awesome benefit, although it can be very tricky to get rates if you have specific dates you're staying in a specific destination. And they're always adding more benefits, which is awesome.

I also like the culture that Hilton provides. All of the senior leaders I have met or have seen speak are very down to earth and seem genuinely warm and friendly. It's a very positive environment.
cons:
It can be difficult to work through the corporate system to get things accomplished sometimes.

The health plans are not very good. All plans from this past year at least require coinsurance. Yes it's less money coming out of my paycheck, but knowing I have to pay 30% of any medical procedure makes me less likely to want to go to the doctor when I need it. Which I think is a horrible way to provide health insurance. I am having a baby this year, and it stresses me out knowing I have to pay thousands more in the end than I did with my first baby (I had a different management company and different medical plans, where the costs were much more straightforward). Even getting lab work done can end up costing hundreds of dollars with co-insurance, instead of a flat charge when I actually go to the lab.

review_title: My job was in a new area for me and I felt like I was able to make a difference.

review_title: Joining Hilton Birmingham Metropole? Things to consider.....

review_title: The Work From  Home Part Time Position Is Not As Amazing As They Say It Is.

job_title: Night Auditor, Front Desk, Breakfast Attendant in Flowood, MS

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Myrtle Beach, SC
pros: Great coworkers, awesome benefits, interesting job location, great training. Learning about Hilton in general gets your foot in the door for future positions if you can see yourself with the company for many years.

review_title: A glimpse on my Hilton journey
pros:
No matter what stage of our carrier, Hilton offer us continuous challenges, opportunities and learning platforms to grow and keep developing our skills.
At the same time the "humanization philosophy" of the company makes every single team member fill proud of its contribution to a global goal.
cons: Although is not a negative point, and actually a common environment at global scale companies, it is crucial to set up daily priorities among simultaneously relevant projects and have the ability to cultivate a good work/balanced life. This could be challenging sometimes.

pros: Hilton is an employee focused company that embraces work/life balance. They provide ample training and mentorship for their employees in order to grow their career.  They have strong benefits for their employees that are easy to access and take advantage of.
cons: In some areas the salary tends to be lower than market due to the benefits they provide like 401K match, robust PTO program, bonus, paid MAT/PAT/Adoption leave and affordable health benefits.

pros: Great management, benefits, and work environment! I am never afraid to ask questions, and got the proper training I needed when first starting. You also have flexibility over your schedule, and are actually able to use your PTO without worry.

pros:
401K is up to a 5% match

Depending on your union the pay can be decent

The code of conduct creates a drama free atmosphere adding to their beneficial work/life balance business model.

Forbes magazine added it to their top 100 best places to work
cons: Sometimes I feel that not all dedicated to the company's waste managment goal of cutting our company wide food waste down 50% by 2030. I also feel that 2030 is too long.

review_title: If you're an incompetent programmer, you will have many opportunities to advance into the senior management jobs.
pros: Hilton Hotels has a large IT community, thanks to the merger it had with Promus some years back.  The nature of IT to create software and other apps for the business is commendable.  It is primarily a Microsoft organization, but there are other opportunities for Unix, Java, and VLDB work.  It is also a great place for aggressive, ladder-climbing people who are looking for a high-level management position.
cons: Unfortunately, there is far too much upper management within the IT group.  We often see first-year programmers reporting directly to directors.  We also often see far too many levels of management, layered within a department whose primary function should be to provide the best product for our guests and the personnel who interact directly with the guests.  Hilton also has a strange habit of promoting employees for odd and often unknown reasons.  Never have I seen a better working example of the saying: "Those who can, work; those who cannot, manage." (paraphrased)  Also, the obscene amount of high-level managers invariably leads to incredibly slow and irrational decisions.  Couple this with with a development cycle that looks a little like Agile, and you have a preponderance of chaos with people constantly running around with their hair on fire.  For the employees in the trenches who spend most of their time fixing the junk that the outsourced consultants manage to continually churn out, promotions are non-existent.  All exempt employees (programmers) who genuinely work hard and are good at what they do will never find themselves in a different position, because everything would grind to a halt without them.    It is true that, once in a position, a Hilton programmer will never advance.  One other thing is the pathetic health and dental plans that keep getting more expensive and less effective year by year.

With Blackstone, the focus is the bottom line and how they can make it "look" better, regardless of what it does to moral.

review_title: I work full time as a Guest Service Agent at the largest hotel in the state of Louisiana.

review_title: You never know who you'll talk to next.
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Independence, MO
pros: Work is relatively easy, and the people you work with are great. Lots of free time to do what you like on a computer, great occupation for someone going to school.
cons: Poor management. Awful customers. Rarely is anyone truly backed for the decisions they make on the spot when it comes to a tough customer, even if dealt with by-the-book. There is always someone saying,"Well, you should've told them..."

review_title: Decent money when scheduled; Old facility and a franchised Hilton owned by a company that mismanages it.
pros: You can make decent money as a server, especially over the summer.  I liked most of the people I worked with, including my managers.
cons: When it's slow, though, you don't get scheduled much, and seniority plays a huge role in scheduling.  It's a Hilton in name only.  The hotel is franchised and is actually owned by First Hospitality Group.  They own a number of different hotels in the Chicagoland area.  Their overall management of the facility could use quite a bit of work.

review_title: Great Place - Needs some new department managers
pros: Benefits are good; lots of team member appreciation and recognition. Lots of ways to go above and beyond your job and be apart of other departments working toward a goal. Management is always looking to improve hotel.
cons: Attendance policy is really strict. Recreation department manager needs to go. Transferring from department to department or to other hotel has a lot of requirements as well.

pros: They do have some area's where the salary is competitive, you'll find a lot of friendly co-workers, several corporate social events a year, and they work hard on opportunities to get involved in the community.
cons: The wrong people get recognized by upper management and promoted. These individuals who are promoted do not promote good company culture or support positive morale. It's really important for upper management to listen to feedback so they can help guide the correct culture for the whole team.

pros: I have been happily working for Hilton Worldwide for over 15 years...  because it is a GREAT company to work for. If you have a true passion for hospitality, want to work with managers and team members who value one another, Hilton is a great choice for you. There are great training programs and many opportunities for growth and development. I started in a "back of the house" position, at $7.50 an hour, and am now a Director of a department.  I couldn't be happier for this company.
cons: EVERY property and company will go through challenges, its how they recover from it.

pros: If you would like to be exploited like a slave, the Hilton hotels are best place for that.
cons: A terrible place to work with no promotions for the experienced staff (trained and working for more than a year). The  Room Attendants are pushed  to do a room for a half an hour , but some of rooms are left like a pigsty, as a result you can see an awful reviews and pictures about the hotel and the rooms: poor maintained, friendly staff, unfriendly bosses, disgusting dusty bathroom fan covers, cracked bathroom tiles, cracked paint, scratched wooden furnish, dirty carpets, and expensive price... It may be better to book a room in a hostel!

pros: Global company that makes it easy to transfer to different properties around the world. Amazing online university with thousands of free development courses. Stafftravel is very cheap and convenient - on average the rate is 35$ for focused service brands, 45$ for full service brands and 55$ for luxury and lifestyle brands.
cons: Properties can be franchised, can be managed or owned, so depending on the property you work at (especially abroad) the owners (not Hilton) can pretty much do whatever they want to the staff.

review_title: Great place to build a future.
job_title: Director of Sales and Marketing in Detroit, MI
pros:
Ethics - Hilton has high ethical standards in how they treat team members, customers and the community.  
Empowerment - I am allowed to try new ideas and to fail.
Best in Class - I take pride in knowing that I work for an industry leader in technology strategy and development.
Opportunity - Once you get your "foot in the door" there is great opportunity for advancement across the entire world.
Benefits - Great insurance, 401K matching, paid time off and hotel discounts!
cons: Hospitality industry is not for everybody. You have to care about others and take pride in your work to succeed.

pros: They provide several trainings and have monthly meeting with team members to share hotel's performance and what the hotel has been doing or planning to do. The hotel also recognises the people quite well. Other team member are friendly as well.
cons: Workload can be a bit too much and manager often did not understand what front liners face everyday. I found that what departmental manager said often contradict with their action or policies they created, which was confusing for us.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked
pros: The benefits are unparalleled, and are constantly being improved and revisited. The climate is friendly and there is a lot of opportunity and push to grow. I have never worked at a more appreciative company, be it Team Member Appreciation Week or the family events and outings, the little drops at the desk of surprises, the works pace is nice and also flexible. Hilton brings out the best in its Team Members by giving them flexibility, autonomy, growth potential, consistent feedback and reviews.
cons: We run out of office space quickly here, but there is flexibility to work remotely  sometimes.

review_title: Do not consider working for a corporate Hilton Hotel.
job_title: Front Desk Associate in Naperville, IL
pros: When times are good, times are good, and the hours come steadily. Working with customers can be great, and giving good service is worthwhile. When a customer is happy, they'll let you know. Worldwide corporation, so it looks good on a resume at least, and there are a ton of skills to be learned from the position that appear good, even when you really do very little in the position. If you're into repetition constantly, saying the same routine with no change, involving little to no thought, where mediocrity (and until just recently outright incompetence) is viewed by the management as acceptable, well then, this is your gig. It sounds great on a resume, if you can hide the fact that you were a zombie.
cons: Almost everything else, and some of the above, is a downside. Being forced to cheapskate the living hell out of customers and not being able to be flexible. Nothing ever free. Ever. Getting screamed at by customers for basically all policies of the hotel and NEVER having a manager back you up. Ever. Being harassed by management when a customer gets angry for something out of your control - and still being told that it was your fault. But when a manager gets an angry customer though, they act nonchalant and almost encourage the guest to complain - their rear isn't on the line, why should they give a crap? But if an associate gets the exact same thing, holy crap, job in jeopardy. Working with a managerial staff that is so obsessed with profit maximization and bowing to corporate that they care not about true service - instead thinking the definition of customer service is smiling at customers, using their name. At the same time, they rape their clients' checking accounts with dishonest charges and fees - and thinking these little, worthless gestures forgive this horrible business practice. Also a horrid culture of communication, and blame is the name of the game. daily accusations of poor performance. Constant threat of termination, and having hours cut at random with no regard to personal needs. Being forced to partake in shady, shady, shaaady business practices. Most of all, running on a business model, office protocols, software, and almost everything ridiculously outdated from the mid-1990s. Yes, it's that bad.

review_title: Good for the resume but Hilton burns you out quickly!
pros: Reputable company in hospitality.  You can get a lot of hands on experience in short timeframe.  Benefits were decent however there is great room for improvement.
cons: Incredibly long and erratic hours for not enough pay.  Burns you out very quickly.  VERY high turnover.  Not enough recognition for a job well done in many cases.

job_title: Senior Sous Chef in Lexington-Fayette, KY

review_title: Not what this company professes to be
pros: Large company. Advanced systems. Progressive.
cons: This company is not what it claims itself to be. All the talk about being a people company is simply that, just talk. They care about one thing only and that is lining the pockets of Blackstone even at the expense of their guests and employees lives. review_title: The Great, The Unhealthy, The Sad and Some Thought-Provoking Questions for Hilton Resort at Bell Rock, Sedona
job_title: Front Desk Coordinator in Sedona, AZ
pros: Overall a great gathering of wonderful people at Hilton Sedona Athletic Club and Eforea Spa---as shared in a recent, 5 star Google review (for them)---especially the majority of massage therapists, front desk agents, spa attendants, accounting department, engineer dept, most aspects of management, members of the club, locals, and even guests.
cons:
1) For a few months, several coworkers and I---front desk agents, massage therapists, and a spa attendant---have been experiencing various symptoms, and some recurring  (i.e., nausea, dizziness, increased allergies, chest pressure, vomiting, hives, fatigue, breathing difficulty, etc.).

Since there has been an issue (for several months) with recurring leaks in certain areas of different ceilings within the building (whenever it rains)---which then gets exposed to hot weather---we all concluded that our symptoms were more than likely from being exposed to toxic mold (that was also visible in certain areas like the massage therapy rest area).

Even members of the club have pointed mold out in the shower areas, which was emailed to management.

One coworker was hospitalized for pneumonia and a bacterial respiratory issue, which she apparently brought up to our higher management that mold may have been the cause; however, nothing was done to our knowledge. 

In addition, we've had very filthy filters for several months due to a lack of cleaning in these areas, which more than likely worsened these already occurring symptoms. 

I reminded management about the filthy filters, even though I found out that they had known about this issue for a while, but it was understandable why they became irritated since they didn't make it a priority to fix it several months ago (when it was shown to one of them directly).

I highly respect and admire many qualities of our management team, mostly our Manager, Asst Mgr, and Director; I barely know the GM, though I've witnessed him showing a few thoughtful gestures towards his employees.

However, I wondered if they---especially the OWNER of this franchise Hilton---truly care about the health and well-being of their staff. Or is it all about hotel profits?

2) The front desk coordinators and spa attendants deserve MUCH better pay. 

You can't expect above and beyond performance and customer service---for an international company/corporation known for its hospitality---when you're not even willing to meet your employees halfway. 

The professional burger flipping guys at In and Out Burger get paid starting $12.50/hour in Prescott, while front desk coordinators at HILTON RESORT IN SEDONA get paid a measly $11.25/hr (and spa attendants less than that); 

YET, front desk coordinators are also expected to do their job (to the fullest) AND spa attendant duties whenever spa attendants are not available for shifts, even during super busy spring break season. 

A couple of club members---very kind and generous older lady and elderly lady---helped clean the women's locker rooms one day because we lacked staff.

3) The food at the employee, mini cafeteria may be free, but the quality seems to be less than that of any dollar menu at fast food joints. 

I have no doubt that IF some of the typical food pics went viral, Hilton would NOT be proud of them, but rather, embarrassed, and even ashamed.

So what's way off about this whole picture? Everything, considering Hilton employees are often reminded of how well this Hilton is doing when it comes to numbers, percentages, and profit.

review_title: Hotel/Real Estate Values Fluctuate, Employees are True Assets
pros:
People and perks. There are many exceptional team members, a lot of industry longevity and knowledge. The experience you gain is invaluable. The work atmosphere can be extremely fun. Middle management has some true all stars. Oh yes...and we also have a fantastic portfolio of hotels.  

The corporate initiatives that have to do with charity, the arts, community involvement and the environment are refreshing. 

There is a definite atmosphere of pride and many people willing to go the extra mile. We also have a wonderful legacy of hospitality and the spirit of Conrad Hilton is definitely still alive.
cons:
Since new ownership, focus is on bottom line rather than hospitality. While there are many things that make Hilton a great company to work for, these are like torches carried on from the old regime.  

There is a lot of training but it is sort of bizarre and hollow as if they train you with catch phrases and slogans but never actually get to the bulk of the knowledge. Trial by fire and piecemeal come to mind. 

Employee morale is low with all the changes-Original Sr. Management is all gone, positions being eliminated and many employees will have to move across country or give up their jobs just to relocate to DC area. Is there a connection with new CEO returning to his home town? The excuse that DC (EDT) is more conducive to a global operation is laughable when a lot of expansion is happening in Asia and India.

review_title: Wonderful Place to Work and make money.
pros: PAy,Benefits,PTO, Come to work when you want.
cons: Working so much that you dont have a life. You get old lose sleep but you still have to pay those bills......Sometimes I wish I had a regular 9-5. You would be better off if you were part time so you can enjoy life and spend more time with your family.

pros: The staff are always great and friendly. Benefits were great as well. The best part is how they focus on team work. Mangers would come and help at the desk when it got busy. Most of the customers would be in happy moods.

pros: Hilton's Property Internship Program is a great way to get your foot in the door in the hospitality industry. I applied with no direct hospitality experience and learned more than I could imagine about this industry in just one summer. cons: The only con I would have to say is that it depends which tasks you are given at the specific property you're at. Sometimes the work I was given was a little tedious, but don't be afraid to ask the managers for more challenging work.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Great opportunities to live and work around the globe if you're interested in relocating
- Depending on which team you're in you may learn a lot
- Half-decent benefits
- Good for those who enjoy traveling for business
cons:
- Corporate team members are generally not best in class and many seem to have fallen into their positions without much real expertise, especially the marketing team. 
- Very difficult to make changes quickly as there are too many people, some of whom do the same jobs but are in different. 
- Male dominated culture with old-school attitudes (as you would expect in the hotel industry). Not forward thinking or progressive. 
- General lack of respect for female team members because the company is hierarchical  and male dominated i.e General Managers, Hotel Owners, Senior Mgmt tend to be male and operate as if it is still 1982. 
- Terrible team member travel program. Completely pointless - just for show. 
- There is so much apathy within the company and so many people who are jobsworths, no real innovation is possible. Teams don't work in harmony with each other. There is a lot of distrust between hotel teams and corporate teams and also within the corporate side itself.

job_title: Cluster Assistant Sales Manager in Tangier, Tanger-Tétouan

review_title: Hilton is an open door to career oportunities

Working within Hilton, you have good career opportunities, either within the property or internationally based on the team members preference/availability.

review_title: New employee and dazzled thus far
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Dublin, CA

cons: The starting pay is laughably low. I would probably make as much working in fast food or starbucks. Paying rent on that low of pay is barely possible. This is the only reason I have to potentially leave my job.

review_title: Too demanding on property level management.
pros: Hilton is on the rise since coming out of private ownership by the Blackstone Group.  The IPO has left the company seeing an infusion of capital into the owned assets with renovations in New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Waikiki.   Also the grip on the pursestrings have loosened up some as we are setting more progressive salaries as the company is finally learning that they can't be the premier hotel organization by being cheap with wages and benefits.
cons:
The demands corporate has placed on the property leaders is enormous.   Demands from pushing the culture, rolling out and testing various projects that consume our time.  The most disturbing evolution has been the demands of the Office of Operational Excellence.  These are efficiency people who come in with a dollar figure in cuts in their head and look for ways of achieving it.  Armed with data they cut staffing and shifts and put in half baked tools to create efficiencies that are not tested but local management is held accountable.   They ignore objections by management and commit to changes to Senior Leadership that , if not achieved, can cost you your job.  Of course they are not there to deal with employee pushback, customer dissatisfaction and local management is left looking like tyrants.

Each day gets harder and harder for local leaders to focus on anything but achieving financial results.

pros: Hilton is a successful international company, and while I interned for a short time, I could feel the hospitality among employees and it really delivers to the guests. review_title: Great place to work, every where you go there are downfalls.

review_title: I love my job at Hilton!
pros: Hilton offers a great environment in offices around the globe. There's lots of internal opportunities to grow and learn, relocate and develop your skills.  For a large company it has a unique entrepreneurial culture that helps push the borders of the industry - especially in the digital and mobile space.  I've been so happy with my benefits, the travel perks, my salary and my work/life balance.  It's nice to be part of a large, stable company that knows where it is headed.
cons: Some internal systems are still old and limit fast change

pros: Benefits turn out to be quite handy beside their leniency in traditional standards to try and push forward. Lotsof opportunities within company and perks come practically out of nowhere.
cons: VERY strict time-clock rules are about the only true 'con' that I have asides from security doing their job with bag checks and only being allowed to enter/exit from one exact point in the hotel.

pros:
Hilton is an awesome company to work for.  The team member travel benefit is amazing and has let me stay in hotels in places I would never have been able to afford at insane rates.  The people are all generally really fun and there is a good sense of camaraderie on the teams.
The position itself is easy which is a plus. You also get really good hospitality industry knowledge by interfacing with so many stakeholders across revenue management, operations and digital.
cons:
You spend at least a quarter of your time just explaining the weekly variances between website revenue vs sites like expedia.  Once you find the reason for that variance you are then tasked to come up with a plan, using no budget, to improve the hotel’s performance.
Very silo'd.  The eCommerce team has zero impact on the actual PPC strategy for hotels' day to day campaigns.  If you want to do anything creative, you have to extract additional funds from hotels which is akin to pulling teeth.  
The role essentially boils down to letting the hotel know what happened last month and answering questions about why something is up or down while in the background you complete large checklists, content and image audits.

pros:
*Work from home
*Good insurance benefits
*Some colleagues and managers are good people.  Despite my following complaints, I've actually made quite a few good friends here.
*It's a pretty sweet deal if you can work your way into a management position.  Then, you can stand around chatting all day, take 3 hour lunch breaks, and go to "leadership conferences" aka eating and drinking on Hilton's dime while your subordinates are being worked to death.
cons:
*Overall, the environment is toxic/gossipy/negative.
*Most managers are incompetent, upper management especially is out of touch.  With a few exceptions, most of the managers do not know how to effectively manage people.  They turn to micro-managing because they don't know what else to do.  Everything you say and do is constantly scrutinized and picked apart.  
*Well, it's a call center job.  Like any call center job, you are treated like just a number.  Basically, expect to be treated like a call-taking robot.  Your manager will not care if you are sick, if a family member is sick or if a close friend just died.  You exist to take calls, your individual life circumstances simply do not matter here.
*Extremely repetitive, you are basically saying the same thing and answering the same questions all day long.
*Calls are nonstop all day, no time to take a breath or a sip of water between calls.  Be prepared to take a lot of abuse by people who act like hotel reservations are a matter of life and death. 
*They say scheduling is flexible; what that means is that YOU will be flexible for THEM, expect no work/life balance if you're on a full-time set schedule.  After being there for 10 years, I was rewarded by being forced to move from a decent daytime schedule to working an overnight schedule. Totally ridiculous and impossible to have any sort of life outside of work with that sort of schedule.  
*Team member travel rate is very difficult to find available, even when booking a year in advance.  Good luck finding a date where the rate is available AND you can get PTO approved to actually go.  It's a joke.

I actually liked the job when I first started, but it's changed a lot over the past several years.  The overall employee morale has seriously declined and it's obvious why.  By the end of my time here, I developed serious problems with anxiety and depression.  Getting out of there has been life changing in the best possible way.  It might be tolerable for someone who is just part-time, build a schedule and can give hours away.  But relying on this job as your sole source of income and working 40+ hours a week was honestly soul-crushing.

review_title: Not bad...but I'm not a fan...
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Great benefits (you can get a room for as low as $35 per night and your family/friends for up to half of the "best available rate" - aka BAR); lots of PTO time accrued pretty quickly; and their health benefits were not so bad.
If you like customer service (which I LOVE most of the time) this is the place to be!
I would work for Hilton again but only if I was working an administrative job or work from home.
cons:
I'm not a fan of standing on my feet all day
I'm also not a fan of working on the holidays and my first year at the property I worked at, I was scheduled for EVERY holiday.
Management does NOT listen to their employees and can actually be a bit unreasonable.
Management also took way too long to replace the shock resistant floor mats at the front desk.  I asked them for OVER  a year and come to find out they were waiting until the renovations on the front desk area was done!!!
Housekeeping is HORRIBLE! Many times on a  Saturday or Sunday they wouldn't have enough rooms cleaned so many of the guests could not check in at check in time; MANY times we received calls from guests that their room was not cleaned (and it actually wasn't!); they wouldn't stock the rooms correctly; and there were a couple of times when I, a front desk agent, had to go make beds because housekeeping didn't do it or used dirty/soiled linen to make the beds.
Maintenance was also horrible!  The HVAC was a two pipe system, which meant that the guests could not control the temp in their room so we would often get calls about it being too hot or too cold.  Once the renovations were done the HVAC was STILL an issue because someone thought it would be a good idea to have the guests wait 30 minutes in their room  before the air/heat would kick on and if they left the room prior to the 30 minute mark the air/heat would not kick on!!! VERY often we would get calls from guests that their tv was not working.

pros: Hilton does a great job of promoting work-life balance and career growth. From what I have seen, managers are  dedicated to helping their team grow and learn throughout every step of their career. The company also takes time and effort to make sure their team members are happy and are taking pride in their work and company.
cons: Transitioning from a smaller company to a company like Hilton can be daunting, as most processes are very set in stone, but everyone is very helpful and they will do their best to help you and guide you.

pros: Fun coworkers at a large 500 room suite hotel.  I had great experience learning to deal with corporate clients and on weekends with wedding and social clients.  Free meal in the cafeteria for lunch.  Great travel benefits through Hilton for full and part time staff.  Free parking for staff too.
cons: Large hotel so very busy and must be prepared to be busy.  TTC route is north of Steels so considered 2 zones.

review_title: Don't take this job unless you like selling!
job_title: Work From Home Customer Service Representative
pros: Part-time, Hilton discounts, build your schedule, Hilton provides equipment
cons: Do NOT accept this position unless you REALLY like being in sales. Although it initially doesn't "appear" to be a sales job, it is! We trained for 3 weeks. During that time, we were told that we would be soft selling the HGV (Hilton Grand Vacations) - fancy words for timeshare. We would ask the guest at the end of the call if they'd be interested in learning more - if yes, transfer to HGV team, if no, thank them and end the call.  Pump the breaks - hold on! Because I swear, everyone was so nice and patient with us during training, but no lie ...it seems like someone threw a switch on my NHC because he became someone different and not for the better.  Immediately after training - during the "nesting" period, and I do mean IMMEDIATELY like a couple of days fresh out of training and a day or two taking calls, we were scheduled to meet with our NHC (New Hire Concierge). During that time, our call/calls were scruntinized, criticized and evaluated. I expected that, BUT NOT AFTER ONLY ONE OR TWO DAYS FRESH OUT OF TRAINING. Are you kidding me? AND...it became painfully clear in the several group/individual meetings immediately following training that the HGV "soft sell" was bogus. Your metric numbers and even pay are hinged on your conversion rate - how many callers that are "lookers" become "bookers" (as they say). I was told that there would be 10 weeks of "probationary" work before we were graduated to the virtual sales floor. However, if our metrics and numbers and whatever else wasn't up to par, we'd be booted. We were told we'd be meeting with the NHC 2-3 times/week for discussion and there is some system in place that "knows" when we're asking the right questions or not. There is clear evidence of serious micro managing with this position. I did like the Hilton Honors discount for employees, but not enough to stick it out. I gladly resigned very shortly after training - no regrets! It's a good gig IF you like the pressure of sales and don't mind the micro managing. But if you're like me, you're going to hate it.

review_title: SALARY / BENEFITS of  EMPLOYEE/ JOB SECURITY  ON  THE CURRENT MARKET SITUATIONS
pros: I learned the multitasking skills  from diff. sections of Finance with good results without hampering my personal life goals

review_title: Well trained staff,and its a great chain hotel worldwide

review_title: good company benefits and perks, poor alignment of corporate priorities in local decisions
pros: Compared to many other hotels I worked with, benefits were great from 401K with matching to free nights at corporate owned hotels. The compensation plan for sales was also robust and motivating.
cons:
There often seemed to be a disconnect between company leadership and local hotel leadership with a lot of eye-rolling on the local level when new programs were rolled out.

pros: I'm a military wife, and this job and soon to be career gives me the freedom, to choose the hours I need around my busy schedule of military life. My family and I love the benefit of getting a deep discount on the rooms, that's one of the best parts. Also they treat me like a full-time employee even though I'm just part-time! I have already started earning PTO.
cons: I'm sure everyone has cons to a job....but not this one. From training to doing the job you are suppose to do, they will be by your side.

pros:
This is taken for granted…The Brand name is equivalent to a “Hotel”, one of the biggest hospitality companies, located in almost every corner in the world. Definitely there are more chances and opportunities in the current and pipelines. 

What I like most about this company is the commitment to employees and the standardized bottom-up approaches in almost all initiatives and programs. Regardless of joining an entry or senior level, there are tremendous opportunities for growth and development. The succession planning and talent retaining reaches for the “grandchild” of each position, and every employee is taken care of to enhance performance. 

A step inside this company means open doors for job security, career growth, development opportunities, rewarded performance, and… I can go on listing advantages! 

I stepped up to 3 challenging roles in 5 years! This is a real achievement for someone who joined the entry level, and who is first time ever working for hospitality industry. 
It is a family, and the standards and opportunities are the same there everywhere. You have the chance to be transferred and hunt opportunities, to choose among 13 Hilton Brands, more than 4800 properties, in about 104 countries.  Above all, the basic factor is that you have the willingness, and passion to grow!

Isn’t it enough to mention that the companies corporate responsibility is to create meaningful opportunities for individuals to reach their full potential, to strengthen communities where Hilton operates, and to preserve environments through the measurement, analysis and improvement of the company’s use of natural resources?
I am really passionate and overwhelmed by the capacities of Hilton Worldwide. 

For me, it is a school where we learn and develop, and it is a pool where we fish for opportunities and benefits! 
This is the perception and impression of thousands of Hilton employees around the world!
cons: I have long-term plans with Hilton and simply I wouldn't commit my time and efforts if I see any cons. That's true, there are no cons I can specify.

review_title: Great place to develop your career

cons: As Hilton is a historical hospitality company, some hotels which is quite old needs really to be push up to be up to date, technology & designs development is going with high tech. all over the world and it's required to keep our company #1 in the industry.

cons: It is like any large organization and there can be some challenges working with all of the different business groups and brands. review_title: Change is happening and the flexible will survive.
pros:
Hilton is in tranformation mode as the company tries to shake off it's former image of traditional big boxes in major cities to being a world class hospitality company.  But at it's roots are the Team Members who make the hotels great.  Each day, throughout the country i am proud to be part of the team that delivers exceptional service to our guests.   

While operations and deliverables to our guests have changed and continue to change with Blackstone's leadership, the heart of our hotels are still alive and doing our best for the guests.   The future for HIlton remains strong and the promise of Blackstone's ownership is the core of that promise.  We have grown our Waldorf=Astoria collection by over 10 properties and ownership is going to focus on our nameplate brand HILTON more than Hampton, Homewood, Embassy and Doubletree.

In the long run we do have a great 401 K, Health, Life and Dental benefits that are above average and PTO which we all love!

Learning and Professional Development and Brand Management have been turning out the training and support materials to do a better job so while we are in turmiol as an organization, we are still the best hospitality company in the world.
cons:
CUTS CUT AND CUTS... it is tough with the layoffs and cutbacks.  Team Member events were scaled back and 2009. And the layoffs is worrysome. Not only at the properties as less of us will have to do more but also in Beverly Hills and Memphis... We are told that only 1000 or so will be moving to DC or Memphis when we close HQ in Beverly Hills.  We have some great friends in those locations and they will be missed.

Finally the Blackstone involvement in the company.  This is Chris Nasetta's company to run all the other players in Blackstone need to step back and let Chris run the show.  He has quickly taken the time to learn and understand the culture, he is moving the culture into the direction it needs to go in, and we need less of these fly by high price executives coming in and throwing in a new direction that doesnt necessarily work

review_title: Not bad if you don't plan to make a career of it
job_title: Reservation Sales Agent in Carrollton, TX
pros: Flexible hours, you make your own schedule. Great co-workers. Great employee discount. Have the option to trade hours with other agents to accommodate your schedule.
cons: Management doesn't care about their people, they believe in the three strikes you're out rule. It doesn't matter the circumstances. Work at home agents are encouraged to come onsite for activities, but it's not worth it, they don't care. I would only recommend working from home with Hilton if you are attending school and need a part-time job.

pros: Hilton Worldwide has lots of property's across the world. Lots of opportunity for growth. Great leaders. Pay is reasonable for work required. Very good employee involvement and empowerment. Company has great benefits/perks such as tuition reimbursement, travel discounts for the employee as well as family and friends, and employee cafeteria with free food.
cons: Some front office managers could use improvement on manager to employee communication skills.

pros: This internship was such a great stepping stone for what I obviously hope will be a great career for myself. I have learned so much from everyone in the property I was assigned to and have met so many genuinely nice people. The pay was pretty good for hospitality internships at $15 an hour. I can't imagine working in new york and somehow paying for housing though.
cons:
My only points where I felt that change could be made is that the internship is 10 weeks and the people in my office were very busy and most of the time didn't have much for me to do after about the first 6 weeks. In addition, looking to the future, the travel benefit with Hilton is in-superior to other hospitality companies. I heard all summer about how the employee discounts are almost never available and compared to Marriott where you can go stay at the Ritz whenever you want it's just not enough for me personally. And then with Four Seasons you get an allocated number of completely free nights based on number of years with the company. For myself, I hope to work for a company where I can still have fantastic experiences in my 20s and travel all over when I am not working... and not be limited to staying at a Hampton Inn. 

Additionally, Hilton seems to have lost its way. The luxury brands are not dominant in America, Hilton itself basically abandoned the Conrad brand to build Waldorf Astoria to a pretty OKAY product and I found it difficult to do my job wholeheartedly because I don't feel that the brands represent the quality I want to be a part of when I graduate. Not to mention, they have such few luxury properties (which is what i'm interested in) that I know it would be challenging to even find a hotel with an opening for a recent grad in the area of interest. I hope to work for one of the best companies in hospitality that is really achieving incredible things.

All in all, this was a fantastic experience that I would wholeheartedly recommend as an opportunity for incredible learning to jumpstart a career... mine just won't be with Hilton.

pros:

job_title: Reservation Sales Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: They are pretty fair with raises and options for growth. The perks are great! Hotel discounts and some free.
cons: They are constantly trying to grow and be the best which is not bad but they often change policy and procedure. So one month they could be drilling into your head do this do this do this and then the next month it somewhat changes. That seems to be the only thing that irritates me about this company.

review_title: Relocate to advance in the company.
pros: Clean and organized work place, friendly team members, discount hotel rates (for employees, friends, and family), PTO, free lunch, free parking, and free dry cleaning for uniforms. There were sometimes special events and meals, a big holiday party for everyone, and on rare occasions raffles and prizes. Great for out-of-country interns (they are not called interns but the term has slipped my mind, they start right out of school and only work 1 year per location and then move to a different country); they would get picked up from the airport in the hotel's audi, given a hotel room until they found an apartment, and also an allowance for food while they were at the hotel. They also had the best treatment from management and human resources, and they get better titles without the responsibilities.
cons: High turn-over rate. I witnessed 2 great assistant managers and various great employees leave due to lack of advancement. Positions were available for promotions from within, but the company would hand the responsibility of these open positions to current employees which they accomplished with excellence, and instead of promoting equally qualified employees from within the hotel they would later hire from the outside and have the current employees train their new bosses. There was also a strict "heels only" rule implemented for the women working front desk, there are no chairs/stools in at the front desk area and you would have to be your entire shift standing in heels (which the customers could not even see due to the desk). Sporadic schedules. Aside from the overnight staff, all other employees would alternate from the morning and evening on a day to day basis. Each week was different and sometimes employees would be scheduled to close one night and then open the following very following morning.

review_title: Work at home but still no life
pros: Hotel benefits are pretty great, you get to work from home, that's pretty much it. This is a short term type job rather than a long term career choice.
cons: If you work full time you will never have a life. Always working weekends and requesting time off is not always easy. The hotel discounts are good but finding an available hotel is very difficult (don't plan on staying anywhere on the weekend cause it wont happen), turnover is high with supervisors and they only care about the big picture which is expecting way too much from agents with each call. They also do not like if you have to take medical leave or maternity leave which resulted in a lot of people not coming back after taking leave. Your experience also depends on who you work under. Some supervisors are great and appreciative of what agents do, others barely give a "good job" when you meet all of their ridiculous expectations. Working from home is nice, however their virtual system is constantly having issues, calls get dropped, system freezes and requires you to reboot your entire computer, programs that we use do not work. Even though the issues are on their end they expect you to still be able to work through it, and if it happens enough time they will fire you without warning for having too many issues, even though the issues are on their end. Pay starts low and with yearly raises you would still have to remain with the company for a long time before making a reasonable wage. Full time employees get to bid on a schedule every 6 months but its based on seniority, which means if you've been with the company for less than 3 or 4 years then you'll most likely get a terrible schedule. Work/life balance is also awful and don't even think about getting to spend the holidays with family if they are out of town/state. Also if you ask 3 people the same question you will get 3 different answers. And the hotels are not on the same page as the call center so you get a lot of customers that were told conflicting pieces of information and finding the right answer takes forever....then you get penalized for that.

pros: It's very laid back and great atmosphere. Possibility to make good money. Restaurant is located by the main pools. It's outdoor but covered and has flaps to close during rainy or cold weather. The employees are very nice and laid back for the most part. The travel program and room discounts are amazing if you travel often. Management is usually pretty hands off unless there is an inspection coming up. Usually pretty easy to request time off when needed. They work great around other scheduling demands. The bussers are really good about helping with whatever you need. They have department outings once a year, they pull employees from other resorts to cover and vice versa.
cons: It's outdoor which means no AC or heat and no way to stop bugs. Always spiders in the rafters and ants in the server station. The kitchen is inconsistent with food preparation and presentation. Food is served differently depending on the cook. They are stuck in their ways for the most part. Management is afraid to make waves for the long time servers so they get away with a lot more than they should which causes newer servers to leave. Management makes rules but there's no consequences when people break them. It's outdoor so there's usually no host which means tables sit where they want unless another server grabs them first to sit them in their station. This means there is no fair rotation which leads to resentment among co-workers. There's not a nearby breakroom and since there's no host this means nowhere to take a quick break from the heat, you have to constantly be on floor greeting tables when they walk in.

pros: Great company to work for; good family benefits, especially maternity leave; casual without losing any of the customer service expected; one of the few companies that takes it seriously to treat their employees the same as they treat their guests; on par to continue to grow customer base because really ahead of its competitors with technology
cons: Long hours for management; difficult to continue to move up because of the amount of people working for the company

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Shelton, CT
pros:
Work was fine , they give you a full training on the system before start working, the employee rate was really nice if you had the time to use it, free breakfast if you have somebody to cover. 
Anyway, a lot depends on Management, Hilton just comes to inspect every 6 months if they respect the rules and standards to keep the name of the brand, besides that all depends on management . I had a good management that gave good benefits. If you really LOVE, really LOVE hospitality, you can find your spot and grow in position, but remember, you will still fulfill somebody else's dream when you work for a chain.
cons:
You need to put stools! Is should be a low! Human beings are not made to stand 8 / 10 hours on their feet. My feet and my back were destroyed and I had to spend money on therapeutic massages and conformable shoes, NO shoes are comfortable after standing that much. 
Couldn't use the bathroom when I needed. Sometimes I was only with the house-person,  I had to keep it or hurry all the time. 
I didn't like the fact that you had to wear somebody else's uniform when you start working. 
Also, there is NO welcome letter, email, package, NO Happy Birthday, or anniversary.  
If you book some rooms as a Team Member, after your work termination, Costumer Services that is responsible for checking all employees reservations, Cancel them. Don't book anything under a team member rate hoping to have the chance to enjoy it because you won't. The worst is that they don't even contact you with an email to tell you something. Bad!  Apparently they leave only those under friends and family.  
Costumers treat you really bad, they scream at you if they can't have what they want, I almost cried more than ones,  and I didn't want to bring home the frustration so I wouldn't talk about it, but at night I stared to have spasms to release the stress!
Couldn't hang out with coworkers, you are another "competitor" all times. They really compete against each other! But not a nice and inspiring competition...

pros: Great co-workers and most managers & guests

I went online and updated all the 401K etc..  401K sent to Millennium Trust and is now costing me nearly 1/2 of my 401K to get the balance.  Such BS. And if your honeymoon time is over you will realize only sudden people getting promoted.

review_title: Bad time pressure but good team and management
pros: Free lunch (although many people skip because there is no time). Very approachable, understanding and fair management. I was never scolded or disrespected by any supervisor or manager, they are all good respectful people. Workplace culture is nice and inclusive too. You will be given time to train and learn at the beginning with an experienced housekeeper.
cons: The job is VERY fast-paced and demanding. You have 30 min per check-out & 15 min per stay-over. But the problem is that to stack your trolley and get everything ready for the day takes at least 30 min. And you HAVE TO come before the start of your shift to do this, otherwise you will be already behind when you start. Often there will be no clean linen or amenities left - the staff will hoard these because there isn't simply enough. At the end of your shift there are duties too like rubbish, cleaning corridors, filling chemicals etc. None of this is counted into your work time so it's very hard to get everything done in time. I recommend only working here if you thrive under time pressure and are physically very fit. I felt a real lack of information at the start. I was never given contact numbers, I didn't have a key to get into the hotel, and you won't know shifts until days before. I never got a uniform either. Also I got paid at the end of the month for the previous month, for example for January at the end of February. This is a long time to wait, especially for first month you might have to wait 2 months.

review_title: Freedom to Excel and set the standard
