cons: Hilton's Corporate structure is slowly changing from a hospitality company to a tech company. There are some growing pains.

review_title: Very good company, too many bureacracies though
pros: Professional development, properties all over the world allowing you to try out different places which is great for your career. Benefits and staff rates are also very good!
cons: Too many bureacratic issues, whenever you try to do something there's always lots of approvals to go through, sometimes irrealistic guidelines to each hotel's reality and also as a manager you are asked to do lots of reports.

review_title: All About the Bottom Line and the IPO
pros: Benefits Package, however it differs from hotel to hotel (some have parking, some none; some have free meal, some pay a little).  Employee travel program is good too.  The people I work with are wonderful.  Great company for promotions and for people who really love the hotel business!
cons: Compensation biggest complaint - since Blackstone took over it has been extremely difficult to get additional wage adjustments above the annual 2-3%.  Hiring rates for some hourly positions have stayed the same for many years.  The IPO was front and center so getting all the company could from its workers was the name of the game - they tried PDQ housekeeping productivity plans, they reduced staff using productivity consultants and, combined with an intense and complicated scheduling system (Watson/GLMS which resulted initially in some two hour shifts),  we have been put through the proverbial ringer.   It took time to correct however managers and staff were stressed with additional responsibilities with no increase in pay.  Supervisors and first level managers work the hardest with the least pay or recognition.  Lack of respect for the worker is also shown in the poor budgeting for uniforms and supplies. HR departments can only do so much to show the team member's love yet they get the blame.   All departments should be responsible yet they are not accountable.   Now that Unite-HERE is threatening in some cities, the corporate office is putting their emphasis on the team members this year trying to clean up the mess they started with their tight fiscal policies, demand for 50% flow-through etc.  But they underestimate how intelligent their employees are.  Perhaps the company will succeed in becoming employee-centric, but they need to begin with what they pay their people and how they are treated (including supplies and proper uniform issuing) before they see the dividends in customer service scores and returning guests.

review_title: Overall a good place to work!
pros:
Great place to work with very good benefits and generally friendly and polite people.

You are treated like an adult, good work/life balance, a lot of flexibility depending on where you work and who your line manager is. Growth opportunities are there for the taking.
cons: Not much of a fun or vibrant atmosphere to work in, European headquarters' location not great, lack of interaction between departments, can also be a very corporate environment at times. Although growth opportunities are there, progression can often be sluggish.

job_title: Manager In Development in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The most recognized hotel chain in the world; endless experience in hospitality dealing with guest issues and learning different ways to resolve; great for growth and development and constant turnover means opportunities for promotion
cons: management makes or breaks a property; if management has poor and petty attitudes, so will the team.

pros: The job is pretty easy and everyone is very friendly even though most of my co workers dont speak much english. Its only $2 a day to eat a meal at the break point restaraunt and the food is really good. They have a daily special that is like eating a home cooked meal. If you dont like the special that day than you have a huge selection of other food to choose from like burgers, chicken sandwich, tuna sandwich ect.
cons:
I work the mid shift which is 2:30pm to 11:00pm and have to eat lunch before break point closes at 7:00. To do this I have to go in there ponce I have all the main things done and hope I dont get a  request from a guest wanting something for there room. If I get a call I have to stop eating and deliver the requested items. Our lunch break is not until 8:30, 9:00 or 9:30 at night. Break point is closed and not enough time to run and get food to get back in time to eat at that time. Not to mention that our lunch is not until we are almost done for the day and have an hour or 2 left to work. If you are late from lunch by 1 minute than you lose 15 minutes of pay from your check.

You go through a training orientation day when you start work and they throw a bunch of people from different departments into one class so not everything applies to where you will be working. Since I am doing housekeeping I have to work with dirty linen and you can catch 3 types of hepatitis from it in rare cases. Although rare it would of been nice to know this but they dont put it in the training videos or even talk about it. The only reason I know that you can get hepatitis is because I saw a small piece of paper hanging on the wall in breakpoint one day advertising free shots if you work at hilton to help prevent this. That if great and all but I only stumbled upon this by chance since I had everything done and just decided to read the wall there. They have a discount on hotels program but almost every hotel is not available even in the slowest months of the year. At this time of year our hotel occupancy is only at 10% when I worked today and still nothing. 

I was my hands there constantly because of all the dirty stuff I touch on a dailuy bases there and my hands are cracking so bad from this, cold weather and chenicals I have to use on a daily bases that I am worried about exposing myself to hep or something. I cant even use gloves because there are no gloves in my size to use. They have these yellow ones but you need to put multiple on a day and there is not even close to enough. I have to dig through the boxes of gloves to be lucky to find 1 pair. Most sizes are in womens because the women are the ones who clean the rooms, I only pick up the linen from them afterwords. The union is also very weak in this company and costs $1.00 a day if you want to join. Not bad but it adds up over the year and when only making $10.00 an hour this is alot of money.Overall it just seems like the company doesnt care about there employees very much and am upset I didnt take the other job opportunity when I had the chance. I figured I could work my way up and it would be nice to have the option to change states since Hilton is state and even worldwide. They are open to tranfsering but I am in the process of looking for a new job already. 

The job schedule doesnt bother me to much but it may bother some. The other day I worked 7 days in a row before my 2 day weekend. I come back to work for 3 days and than got another 2 days off. I have heard of some people working 10 days in a row and than getting 4 days off in a row afterwords.

Also since Hilton is a hotel company you do have to work on holidays which is fine but overtime should be included in this. The company does let you use one of you paid vacations if you choose to for an extra 8 hours on your check but its kind of BS if you ask me. In all I dont feel like Hilton cares about its employees very much or at least the Housekeepers who work there.

I would definetly not recommend this job to anybody unless you are desperate like I was when trying to find a job. By the way I have only seen the head of housekeeping 1 time and that is when he introduced himself when he got the new job at out location. It would be nice to see him every once in a while because I dont even know what he does really. He is in his office in a completely different building than where our housekeeping office is located. So I am still really confused about what this guy actually does as a job.

cons: Management. Hilton needs to be more about the companies and properties that these allow to lease their name. My property is owned by Xena and it is an awful property. I've worked for other Hilton hotels and this location is not up to par with Hilton standards.

pros: I was hired to work a great schedule that fit me perfectly. I love the actual jobs description (As in what I was hired to do). It's fun, and for the most part I like the other employees and I get along with people. I also like all the new people I meet and it's fun helping and talking to all the guests. I like to listen to stories from other places and help people find good local spots to visit.
cons:
My manager (just her literally everyone else is awesome) is the most disorganized, incompetent, annoying woman I have ever had to work with. When I started the job there was another woman in that position. She was cool. Knew what she was doing. I drive the airport van back and fourth. With her I was never double booked, I was never forced into overtime, and it was never assumed I would do things not in the job description I was always asked first. After a month that manager left and was replaced with a new one. New manager is a walking nightmare. So far this is all that's happened:

1. Expects me to be two places at once (as in picking up someone from the hotel while also dropping off someone at the airport) 
2. Doesn't understand that it takes 20 minutes AT LEAST to get to the airport and on a good day. I drive during the heaviest rush hour times imaginable. Every day there's a least one run where it's going to take 45 minutes. That's just how it is. She I guess assumes that I am slacking off when I'm stuck in bumper to bumper traffic. 
3. The schedule isn't under my control. At all. So I just do what's already written for me. If someone else double books me it's apparently now MY fault. Which I can do nothing about. I have no control of anything. The vans are supposed to run every half hour, they don't. 
4. Several times I've gotten told to pick up someone at the airport. They don't give me a name of who I'm looking for or a gender. Just that I have a pick up. Several times this has resulted in no one actually being at the air port. 
5. Manager seemingly only enforces the dress code with me. Other drivers show up consistently not wearing the assigned uniform. If I show up with my shirt slightly untucked I get in trouble. 
6. Manager has been informed repeatedly that I have work restrictions due to a documented disability. Manager gets pissy when I explain to her I cannot do certain tasks (or work overtime) due to physical restrictions. 
7. Allows the front desk girls to designate pickup areas outside of the 5 mile radius that is within hotel policy then gets upset with me when I do as I'm told and pick these people up. For example: A woman wanted a ride at least 25 miles away from the hotel (well out of range of the 5 mile policy) front desk girl tells the woman I can take her. When I contest this, I'm told to do it anyway, then later berated for doing what I was told to do. 

The first supervisor literally had NONE of these problems. At all. I was never double booked. She never assumed I'd be working when I wasn't scheduled. She didn't force me to stay hours after my shift. New manager schedules me for days that I'm not supposed to be on then gets upset when I tell her I can't work those days. Makes snide remarks about "Why can't you work like a normal person" even though she also knows I have a disability. As far as I'm aware this specific shift position has had A LOT of walk outs and random quits. If I didn't need the money so bad I would be one of them but as of now there's not much I can do other than suffer.

review_title: Lots of media PR but not much in execution...
pros: PTO time is generous with full -timers generating about 4 weeks per year (same for management and hourly).  The company encourages a lot of community activities, charity, runs, clean ups, etc.    There's plenty of opportunity for advancement.
cons: Pay for management is based on 8 hour weeks but scheduled 10 hour minimum.  There's a lot of barking about how amazing this company is with its benefits Fortune Top 100!!... great in the big picture, but on-site it seems to be just for public appearance.  Everything is political - everywhere, every property.  Plenty of scolding wrongs and almost NO praising of rights.  PTO is generous but it's encouraged to take one day here and there rather than a week or two off for long vacations.  Time off is almost impossible with minimal department staffing.  Training is negligible (at least for management) and micromanagement is condescending and borders on harassment.  Managers are used as pawns, life outside of work is frequently disregarded despite claims of "thriving."  Room benefits are barely acceptable with only certain properties having discounted rates.  Rest of benefits package, including health insurance is average at best.

review_title: The Great, The Unhealthy, The Sad & Some Thought-Provoking Questions For Hilton
pros: Overall a great gathering of wonderful people---as shared in a recent, 5 star Google review (for them)---especially the majority of massage therapists, front desk agents, spa attendants, accounting department, engineer dept, management, HR staff, members of the club, locals, and even guests.
cons:
- For a few months, several coworkers and I---front desk agents, massage therapists, and a spa attendant---have been experiencing various symptoms of being exposed to mold (from recurring leaks in certain areas of different ceilings whenever it rains) and filthy filters due to lack of cleaning (i.e., nausea, dizziness, increased allergies, chest pressure, vomiting, hives, fatigue, etc.). One coworker was hospitalized for pneumonia and a respiratory bacterial infection, which she apparently brought up to our Director that mold may have been the cause. I reminded management about the filthy filters even though I found out that they had known about this issue for a while, and didn’t make it a priority to fix it several months ago. I highly respect and admire many qualities of our management team; however, I wondered if they---especially the owner of this franchise Hilton---truly care about the health and well-being of their staff.
- habitual, passive-aggressive drama from a few employees, which made me question whether or not it was worth working at a place that can often be draining, despite the recurring, fear-based/dense/negative energy coming from a few individuals.
- the front desk coordinators and spa attendants deserve MUCH better pay. You can't expect above and beyond performance and customer service---for an international company/corporation known for its hospitality---when you're not even willing to meet your employees halfway. The professional burger flipping guys at In & Out get paid starting $12.50/hour in Prescott, while front desk coordinators at HILTON IN SEDONA get paid $11.25/hr (and spa attendants less than that). What's way off about that picture? Everything. 
- the food at the employee, mini cafeteria may be free, but the quality seems to be less that that of any dollar menu at fast food joints. I have no doubt that IF some of the typical food pics went viral, Hilton would NOT be proud of them, but rather, embarrassed and/or ashamed.

pros: There are some very nice people working at the specialist and analyst levels. It's a shame that, given the ruthless and toxic work environment that clothes itself in the familial and collegiate, they won't last very long.
cons:
Health benefits are deducted from your paycheck after taxes for your first 90 days, which leaves you with very little take-home pay. The choices of investments offered in the company 401K are very limited, and the T. Rowe Price website is not very user friendly.

Pay is very low, compared to industry standards - about $15,000 to $30,000 less than what you would find elsewhere.

Training is lackluster in some areas, and practically non-existent in others. For a company that claims it spends over $10,000 training new hires, it certainly doesn't show. Criteria for evaluations is not applied consistently - there is a constant "moving of the goal posts," where one evaluator will tell you to do something, and then the next evaluator will tell you that what the last one said was completely wrong, and that you should do the exact opposite. It only sets new hires up for failure. It also ensures job security for instructors and evaluators in RM Enablement, at the expense of the new hires' morale and physical/mental/emotional health.

New Hire Managers do not truly make themselves available to new hires - they don't check in with anyone, and they force everyone to come to them, which is not very convenient, nor is always a viable option. Their one-on-one meetings with employees are not truly about answering questions or hearing concerns, but about enforcing conformity and eliminating all dissent. Furthermore, anything you say will be reported back to Directors and Assistant Directors (despite the New Hire Managers' claims of confidentiality) for the purposes of being used against you later.

Management claims they welcome all feedback and suggestions, but nothing could be further from the truth, especially when it comes to feedback concerning training. RM Enablement - the department responsible for training new hires - does not/cannot tolerate criticism. Those who dare to question or criticize RM Enablement will find themselves being reprimanded or terminated.

There is also a systemic pattern of racism, sexism, and ageism in the RMCC, where certain classes of individuals are routinely punished, denied advancement, denied pay raises, given harsher evaluations and feedback, and subjected to a negative and hostile work environment while others are given preferential treatment. For example, one previous incoming class of Revenue Specialists saw one half of the class (being of a particular gender) breeze through mocks with little or no problems, while the other half was practically raked over the coals for every little thing imaginable.

If you're looking to get into revenue management, I would strongly advise looking elsewhere. Unless you have extensive hospitality experience, the learning curve is just too high. Also, Hilton's training is an absolute joke. You won’t learn anything in their classes, and instructors/evaluators are directed to justify their existence by finding fault with even the littlest of things - when they say “there will always be feedback,” what they really mean is “nothing you do will ever be enough to satisfy us, because if we can't find anything to criticize off-hand, we will go looking for something/anything.”

You will burn out very quickly in that role, and most people don’t last beyond 1-2 years. During that time, this company will stress you out, make you miserable, and generally push you past your breaking point. You will be reduced to a neurotic mess, and that’s if you don’t suffer a nervous breakdown, like I did. (Many people working there are on some type of anti-depressant or anti-anxiety medication - it really is an unhealthy environment)

Do yourself a favor: Stay far away from Hilton. There are other, better opportunities out there.
